Document J000000020050805e18500025


Letters to the Editor
Is There A Housing Bubble?
743 words
4 August 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A13
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Neil Barsky notes in his July 28 op-ed "What Housing Bubble?" that he is not an economist, which is confirmed when he writes, "What we do have is a serious housing shortage . . ." The "shortage" hypothesis is often used in several contexts by the press. National media have reported shortages of engineers, business faculty, teachers, nurses and a host of other professionals. Proponents of these shortages, however, overlook fundamental economic principles. They speak of shortages as though shortages represent some absolute, readily identifiable lack of desirable goods and services. Price is seldom accorded its proper role.

There is never enough of any good or service to satisfy all wants or desires. The consumer must give up something to get something. The buyer must pay the market price and forego whatever else he could have for the same price. The forces of supply and demand determine these prices -- and the price of housing is no exception. The buyer can take it or leave it. However, those who choose to leave it (because of lack of funds or personal preference) must not cry shortage. The good is available at the market price.

All goods and services are scarce, but scarcity and shortages are by no means synonymous. Scarcity is a regrettable and unavoidable fact. Shortages are purely a function of price. The only way in which a shortage has existed, or ever will exist, is in cases where the "going price" has been held below the market-clearing price. Evidence does not suggest that such is the case for the "shortages" which have recently been advanced.

Richard A. Palfin, Ph.D.

Chief Economist

Palfin &Associates, Inc.

Sunnyvale, Calif.

---

Neil Barsky's points were refreshing considering all the hand-wringing over the recent appreciation of home prices. Although prices have risen, there are good reasons. Certainly the 24% drop in mortgage rates since 1999 has been an important factor, and has allowed for greater access to homeownership for a larger portion of the population, but there have been other real and fundamental reasons for the rise.

For instance, the average square footage of new homes built has risen 9%, so though we are paying more for our homes, we are also getting larger living spaces. Or, average hourly wages have increased 17%. It can be argued that home prices are catching up to wages.

And just because home prices have risen is no reason to assume that they are poised to fall dramatically, even in very hot markets. The last time we saw a 13%+ increase in the average new home price was in 1987 and for the next three years prices rose on average 5.4% before finally declining a modest 1.8% in 1991. The downturn lasted one year and in 1992 they began a 14-year up cycle.

In addition, an increasing percentage of new homes built every year are being built by large, well-capitalized, more risk-averse builders who have been leveraging size to get land, labor and materials at better prices then smaller builders are able. Though housing remains cyclical, the public builders have improved their business models in the past 15 years, relying more on optioned land and access to cheaper capital. As a result they have seen their market share more then double and their share prices appreciate an average of 3,000% since 1990.

I have spent a good part of the past four years listening to the media and some in the investing community warn investors to avoid housing stocks because of the "housing bubble." Some day, they may be right. But while they were spending so much time clucking about the sky falling, they were missing the fundamentals on the ground all around them -- and a lot of excellent investing opportunities to boot.

Jeremy Pinchot

Bedford, N.Y.

---

Mr. Barsky's article overlooks several arguments. Historically, the prices in hot markets with household incomes misalign with rents on comparable properties. There is also the role of transitory demand in creating the illusion of a supply shortage, fueled by unsustainably low mortgage rates, speculation and loose credit standards. And he neglects the relationship between rising central bank interest rates and mortgage rates, which has already brought an end to the British housing bubble and will likely soon have a similar effect here.

Stephen Stohs

La Jolla, Calif.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050804000053]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050804e18400010


The Economy
Manufacturing Regains Its Speed --- Factory Activity Picks Up For Second Month in Row; Construction Spending Ebbs
By Zachary A. Goldfarb
580 words
2 August 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

U.S. factory activity in July picked up for the second consecutive month, suggesting the manufacturing sector is continuing to gain momentum after hitting a soft spot late last year.

The Institute for Supply Management, in a survey of more than 400 companies, said its July index of manufacturing activity rose to 56.6 from 53.8 in June, driven by new orders and higher production levels as well as lower prices. Any figure above 50 represents growth in the sector.

"Manufacturing has regained its footing," said National Association of Manufacturers chief economist David Huether.

The increase in factory activity is another sign that the economy may pick up speed in the third quarter. Recent Commerce Department figures indicated strong consumer demand, which surprised manufacturers and led them to draw down inventories to meet sales. Now they are increasing production as more orders arrive.

The improvement may be more evidence for the Federal Reserve that it needs to raise short-term interest rates to prevent the economy from overheating. On the other hand, lower prices may assuage inflation fears that could lead to higher rates.

After growing unusually quickly for part of 2004, the manufacturing sector saw its rate of growth slow down for the seven months starting last November, raising concerns about whether it would see contraction. But in June it picked up again, and with July's increase, "all the signs are that we should have continued momentum through the second half of the year," said ISM's Norbert Ore, the Tempe, Ariz., group's chairman. He cautioned that growth could slow if oil prices continue to rise.

Twelve manufacturing sectors showed growth in the latest report, including the fabricated metals, wood and furniture industries. Mr. Ore said recent initiatives by automotive companies to make employee-pricing available to consumers and the hot housing market were having benefits "down the supply chain," leading to a jump in demand for many of the components for cars and homes. Six industries, including apparel and paper, reported decreased activity last month.

In other economic news, the Commerce Department said construction spending declined in June, and May's figures were revised downward. Total spending in June slid 0.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $1.093 trillion, while May saw a 1.7% decrease to $1.096 trillion, rather than the originally projected 0.9% decrease to $1.103 trillion. Both the June and revised May figures are above what was registered a year earlier.

The most significant decline was in residential construction spending, which fell 0.4% to $609.1 billion. Spending on public nonresidential construction, such as schools and highways, declined 0.5% to $242.4 billion, though spending on private nonresidential construction, such as offices and factories, grew 0.2% to $241.4 billion.

Separately, the National Association of Realtors said its pending-home-sales index in June rose 0.6% from a month earlier to 126.3. The index, which equates the 2001 level of activity to 100, is based on the number of pending sales of previously owned homes for which contracts have been signed but transactions aren't completed. The index was up 3.6% from a year earlier.

---

Online Today: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest economic reports, at WSJ.com/OnlineToday.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050802000115]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050802e18200034


International News
Manufacturing Picks Up in U.S.
A Wall Street Journal News Roundup
384 words
2 August 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A4
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

U.S. factory activity picked up last month, a private research group reported, as new orders and production rose, hiring perked up and price pressures eased.

Separately, U.S. construction spending turned down unexpectedly during June, taking its fourth consecutive drop as residential outlays slid in spite of the hot housing market. Total spending decreased 0.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $1.093 trillion, the Commerce Department said. Spending fell 1.7% in May to $1.096 trillion; it was originally reported as down 0.9% at $1.103 trillion.

The Institute for Supply Management said its July index of manufacturing activity rose to a reading of 56.6 from the 53.8 reading posted in June. Any index reading above 50 indicates expansion in the sector.

"It appears that the sector hit a low point in May, and has rebounded nicely in June and July," said Norbert Ore, chairman of the ISM's manufacturing survey committee. He noted that new orders, which rose to a reading of 60.6 from 57.2 in June, and production, which jumped from 55.6 to a robust 61.2 reading in July, continued to drive improvement in the sector. An index of employment rose to 53.2 after coming in at 49.9 in June.

"The survey is clearly signaling an end to the industrial slowdown," Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics wrote in a note to the research firm's clients. "With consumers happy, too, this is a great start" to the third quarter.

An index of prices in the ISM's report slid into negative territory, registering a reading of 48.5 after coming in at 50.5 in June. Mr. Ore said July's reading "indicates that pricing power, at least for the short term, is now once again favoring buyers." The move below 50 in the price index closes 40 straight months of rising inflation pressures for manufacturers.

The ISM also said inventories continued to contract, at a July reading of 47.5, compared with 47.8 in both June and May.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest U.S. economic reports, at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050801e1820000j


Ahead of the Tape
Ahead of the Tape
By Justin Lahart
450 words
1 August 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
C1
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

[Today's Market Forecast]

Compared With What?

By most measures, it is hard to argue that stocks are anything close to cheap.

A valuation model devised by Yale University's Robert Shiller compares the price of the Standard &Poor's 500-stock index with average annual earnings, under generally accepted accounting principles. The Shiller price/earnings ratio of 29 is well below the peak of 48 hit in December 1999. But before late 1996 -- around when Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan made his "irrational exuberance" speech -- it never was as high as it is now. At the start of the long bull market that began in 1982, it was 11.

A measure from Jim Bianco of Arbor Research, which compares the capitalization of the stock market to gross domestic product, tells a similar story. At 120%, market cap as a percentage of GDP is below the 183% it hit in early 2000. Still, this measure was never north of 100% before early 1997 and was at 33.5% at the start of the bull market.

At the least, the market's high valuation by these measures suggests stocks might not offer much in the way of returns in the years to come. Stocks can go higher only if valuations (like P/Es) go higher or if earnings go higher. It is easier to imagine valuations falling to historic norms than it is to imagine them making another 1990s-style push higher. That leaves earnings, which over time can't grow much faster than GDP, to push stocks higher.

Some bullish strategists say stocks actually are cheap, because interest rates are so low. Bears respond that, at the very least, this only means that stocks are cheap compared with interest-bearing instruments, such as Treasurys.

Houses, on the other hand, don't look cheap compared with almost anything. The National Association of Realtors' Housing Affordability Index measures how easy it is, at current mortgage rates, for a family with an average income to afford an average house. In June, it fell to its least-affordable level since August 1991, when mortgage rates were significantly higher.

An unscientific email sampling Friday of short-sellers and other bearishly inclined investors asked respondents what they would prefer to sink $500,000 into for the next three years, a Florida condo or the Nasdaq-100 Index Tracking Stock exchange-traded fund, better known by its symbol QQQQ, which these people tend to think of as a proxy for speculative excess.

The QQQQ won, hands down.

---

Please send comments and questions to justin.lahart@wsj.com.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050801000034]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050801e1810000v


Heard on the Street
U.S. Mortgage-Backed Securities Soar
By Christine Haughney
786 words
29 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
M8
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Investors' love affair with real estate is producing a record year for U.S. commercial mortgage-backed securities, signaling a further shift in real-estate financing from banks to Wall Street.

Cash is flooding into the market, where mortgages for skyscrapers, strip malls and other commercial properties are bundled together and sold as bonds to investors from pension funds and insurance companies to hedge funds and wealthy investors.

That strong demand, however, is driving down the yields investors receive. Some bankers fear the rush into the bonds may even loosen lending standards, allowing real-estate buyers to borrow more and thus drive up property prices. In other words, investors could be putting themselves at risk if their zealousness to lend by purchasing mortgage bonds causes property buyers to overreach.

"What is supporting real-estate prices?" asks Rob Brennan, who runs Credit Suisse First Boston's real-estate finance and securitization group. "It's the availability of competitively priced debt. That's thanks to the public [commerical mortgage securities] market."

Real-estate owners borrowed $72 billion, or about 60 billion euros, through commercial mortgage-backed issues debt in the first half of 2005, compared with a record $94 billion for all of 2004, according to the Commercial Real Estate Securities Association. The commercial mortgage-backed securities market has grown tenfold during the past decade, with about $500 billion of securities outstanding.

"CMBS is slowly eating away market share from traditional real-estate lenders like banks and life-insurance companies," said John Westerfield, a Morgan Stanley managing director responsible for real-estate lending. That may be why traditional lenders Bank of America Corp. and Wachovia Corp. now also happen to run the leading commercial mortgage-backed securities' operations.

Sam Zell, a well-known real-estate investor and chairman of Equity Office Properties Trust, the biggest office-building owner in the U.S., believes that the commercial mortgage-backed securities market has removed some of the clubbiness in the industry, allowing people to raise funds even if they don't have relationships with bankers. "It's made the overall commercial real-estate market more viable to everybody," Mr. Zell said.

For investors, the insatiable thirst for yield in a low-yield world is driving much of the demand. While yields on the issues have fallen, they still offer higher payouts than most government and corporate bonds. With so many players flooding the commercial mortgage-backed issues market, returns for investors also are less rewarding than in the past: According to J.P. Morgan, the yield on a single-A-rated commercial mortgage-backed securities dropped to 5.23% from 5.88% three years ago, while the yield premium the bonds pay above U.S. Treasury securities dropped to one percentage point from 1.35 percentage points.

"People are taking more risk for less reward," said Ken Cohen, a Lehman Brothers managing director who puts together commercial mortgage-backed securities deals.

The yield advantage to other bonds is still attractive enough for many investors. Putnam Investments, for example, now holds commercial mortgage-backed issues in more than 10% of its active accounts, compared with less than 1% two years ago. "As long as [yield] spreads stay where they are, we're going to be heavily involved," said Rob Bloemker, managing director and team leader of the mortgage-backed securities and government group for Putnam.

Which is why some in the industry fear that real-estate owners will keep borrowing more, a real problem should the property-market pull back. But it isn't just property buyers that are piling in.

"The real pressure is coming from the developers," said Mark Finerman, who heads the real-estate finance group for RBS Greenwich Capital. Indeed, gung-ho developers can get a loan to break ground on a new building in Manhattan for as little as a 5% down payment.

The commercial mortgage-backed issues market grew out of the Resolution Trust Corp., which was created to sell off assets of failed savings-and-loan institutions in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The RTC issued nearly $15 billion of commercial mortgages, which Wall Street firms soon found a way to turn into bonds, with each bond divided into individual "tranches" that allow buyers to pick their preferred level of risk.

Conventional developers were slow to adopt commercial mortgage-backed issues financing. They already had age-old relationships with traditional bankers and insurance companies. While commercial mortgage-backed issues offered better rates, developers disliked the restrictions against paying off debts early and making changes to buildings and having less contact with bankers.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=weco20050729000054]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJE000020050729e17t0001f


Heard on the Street
Commercial-Mortgage Securities Have Record Year
By Christine Haughney
810 words
29 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal Asia
AWSJ
M5
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

Investors' love affair with real estate is producing a record year for U.S. commercial mortgage-backed securities, signaling a further shift in real-estate financing from banks to Wall Street.

Cash is flooding into the market, where mortgages for skyscrapers, strip malls and other commercial properties are bundled together and sold off as bonds to investors from pension funds and insurance companies to hedge funds and wealthy investors.

That strong demand, however, is driving down the yields investors receive. And some bankers fear the rush into the bonds may even loosen lending standards, allowing real-estate buyers to borrow more and thus drive up property prices. In other words, investors could be putting themselves at risk if their zealousness to lend by purchasing mortgage bonds causes property buyers to overreach.

"What is supporting real-estate prices?" asks Rob Brennan, who runs Credit Suisse First Boston's real-estate finance and securitization group. "It's the availability of competitively priced debt. That's thanks to the public CMBS market."

Real-estate owners borrowed $72 billion through CMBS debt in the first half of 2005, compared with a record $94 billion for all of 2004, according to the Commercial Real Estate Securities Association. The CMBS market has grown tenfold during the past decade, with about $500 billion of securities outstanding.

"CMBS is slowly eating away market share from traditional real-estate lenders like banks and life-insurance companies," said John Westerfield, a Morgan Stanley managing director responsible for real-estate lending. That may be why traditional lenders Bank of America Corp. and Wachovia Corp. now also happen to run the leading CMBS operations.

Sam Zell, a well-known real-estate investor and chairman of Equity Office Properties Trust, the biggest office-building owner in the U.S., believes that the CMBS market has removed some of the clubbiness in the industry, allowing people to raise funds even if they don't have relationships with bankers. "It's made the overall commercial real-estate market more viable to everybody," Mr. Zell said.

For CMBS investors, the insatiable thirst for yield in a low-yield world is driving much of the demand. While yields on CMBS bonds have fallen, they still offer higher payouts than most government and corporate bonds. But with so many players flooding the CMBS market, returns for investors also are less rewarding than in the past: According to J.P. Morgan, the yield on a single-A-rated CMBS dropped to 5.23% from 5.88% three years ago, while the yield premium the bonds pay above U.S. Treasury securities dropped to one percentage point from 1.35 percentage points.

"People are taking more risk for less reward," said Ken Cohen, a Lehman Brothers managing director who puts together CMBS deals.

Still, the yield advantage to other bonds is still attractive enough for many investors. Putnam Investments, for example, now holds CMBS in more than 10% of its active accounts, compared with less than 1% two years ago. "As long as [yield] spreads stay where they are, we're going to be heavily involved," said Rob Bloemker, managing director and team leader of the mortgage-backed securities and government group for Putnam.

Which is why some in the industry fear that real-estate owners will keep borrowing more and more, a real problem should the property-market pull back. But it isn't just property buyers that are piling in.

"The real pressure is coming from the developers," said Mark Finerman, who heads the real-estate finance group for RBS Greenwich Capital. Indeed, gung-ho developers can get a loan to break ground on a new building in Manhattan for as little as a 5% down payment.

The CMBS market grew out of the Resolution Trust Corp., which was created to sell off assets of failed savings-and-loan institutions in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The RTC issued nearly $15 billion of commercial mortgages, which Wall Street firms soon found a way to turn into bonds, with each bond divvied up into individual "tranches" that allow buyers to pick their preferred level of risk.

But conventional developers were slow to adopt CMBS financing. They already had age-old relationships with traditional bankers and insurance companies. While CMBS offered better rates, developers disliked the restrictions against paying off debts early and making changes to buildings and having less contact with bankers.

"We stayed away from them for years," said Gentry Hoit, executive vice president of capital transactions for national office landlord Shorenstein Co. That was then: Recently, Shorenstein used CMBS debt to buy office towers like 125 Park Ave. in New York City and 45 Fremont St. in San Francisco.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=waco20050728000095]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050728e17t0002e


The Economy
U.S. Business Spending Picks Up --- Regional Fed Banks Report Robust Factory Activity; Durable-Goods Orders Rise
By Rafael Gerena-Morales
901 words
28 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

After slowing their pace of investment earlier this year, U.S. companies are showing signs of placing bigger bets on equipment like industrial machines, airplanes and computer gear.

That sign of rising confidence among business executives could point to a pickup in overall economic growth in the second half of the year. High oil prices and uncertainty about the global economy had left some economists worried the recovery in business investment could falter, but a wide array of recent reports suggests that investment, like consumer spending, is back on solid footing.

Intel Corp., Boeing Co., and General Electric Co. are among the companies that have reported robust demand for their products in the past few days and weeks. The Federal Reserve said yesterday that its "beige book" -- a compilation of anecdotal reports on the economic outlook from its 12 regional Fed banks -- showed upbeat expectations for factory activity across the nation. Dallas, for example, reported demand for semiconductors had picked up in the past six weeks, while Cleveland said Midwest manufacturers were seeing rising orders.

The Commerce Department lent weight to these anecdotal reports with a monthly release showing that new orders for manufactured durable goods -- products like cars, computers and industrial machinery -- were on the rise. They increased in June by $2.9 billion, or 1.4%, to $215.4 billion, up 6.8% from a year earlier.

Economists watch durable-goods orders closely because they are considered an indicator of future economic activity.

Gains in April and May had been driven by surging orders for airplanes and parts. But the latest report showed a solid underpinning outside that sector. New orders for capital goods other than aircraft and defense -- a closely watched proxy for underlying investment demand -- rose to nearly $69 billion in June, up 3.8% from the month before and 11.1% from a year ago.

"The numbers were somewhat stronger than expected [and] very broad-based," said Joel L. Naroff, president and chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors. "This seems to indicate a fair amount of [business] confidence out there." It also indicates that business investment is "likely to stay solid the rest of the year," he says.

Other indicators suggest the industrial sector and business investment were gathering steam as they entered the second half of the year. Early this month, for instance, the Institute for Supply Management said its monthly survey of supply managers rebounded in June, in part because of a surge in new orders.

Nariman Behravesh, chief economist at Global Insight, a Waltham, Mass., economic-forecasting firm, says executives have been heartened by the economy's resilience in the face of rising oil prices. Businesses also have worked off inventory that built up earlier in the year, he noted. He now expects the economy to expand by as much as 3.8% in the second half, up from an earlier projection of 3.3%.

Yesterday, Boeing attributed a 15% increase in second-quarter revenue to strong global growth, and other companies have made similar pronouncements. Ingersoll-Rand Co., a manufacturer of industrial equipment, last week boosted its full-year earnings guidance, citing strong orders. General Electric reported double-digit orders gains for the second quarter. "It is about as good as I would hope for," Andy Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer, said after announcing a 15% increase in second-quarter revenue last week.

Other reports showed the economy firing on many cylinders. The Commerce Department reported that sales of new, single-family houses in June rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nearly 1.4 million units, a record, up 4% from the month before and 14% from a year ago. Economists took it as yet another sign that the housing boom continues, though the median sales price of new homes fell in June to $214,800, down 5.5% from the previous month.

The price decline didn't necessarily mean sales prices were faltering. It could instead mean that modestly priced homes were gaining market share, noted Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington. Overall, new homes priced at $300,000 and above accounted for 29% of total sales in June, down from 33% in May, according to the Commerce Department. New homes priced between $150,000 to $199,999 accounted for 25%, up from 21% in May.

It has been clear for several weeks now that consumer spending and housing were on a firm footing as the economy moved into the second half. Less certain was the outlook for business investment, which showed some signs of slowing a few months ago -- growing in the first quarter at a 4.1% annual rate, according to the Commerce Department, the slowest pace since early 2003. And orders for durables goods declined during the first three months of the year.

Economists say the slowdown was partly tied to the expiration of tax incentives last year, which encouraged businesses to make investments in 2004 while the incentives still applied. The latest reports indicated that businesses have shrugged off uncertainties and are poised to resume robust spending on equipment, economists say.

---

Online Today: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest economic reports, at WSJ.com/OnlineToday.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050728000168]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050728e17s0003s


What Housing Bubble?
By Neil Barsky
1308 words
28 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A10
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

If you want to be scared out of your wits these days, you basically have two choices: go watch Steven Spielberg's latest, or listen to the hysterical warnings of economists and journalists about the imminent popping of our so-called housing bubble. Robert Shiller, the ubiquitous Yale economist, says home prices could fall 50% from their peak. Taking things a step further, The Economist recently went so far as to call the global housing boom "the biggest bubble in history."

In a free country, it is fair game for the media and economists to scare homeowners with words of gloom and doom, however knee-jerk, consensual and misguided they may be. But housing is a serious business; for most of us, it is our most valuable asset. For generations of immigrants, home ownership has represented the realization of the American dream.

The reality is this: There is no housing bubble in this country. Our strong housing market is a function of myriad factors with real economic underpinnings: low interest rates, local job growth, the emotional attachment one has for one's home, one's view of one's future earning-power, and parental contributions, all have done their part to contribute to rising home prices. Over the past quarter-century, there has been an explosion of second-home purchases, a continued influx of immigrants, and a significant reduction in existing housing inventory through tear-downs. Not all of these trends are accurately reflected in the unending stream of data published daily. Home prices on average have risen at a 6% annual pace since 1999, and 13% over the past year.

What we do have is a serious housing shortage and housing affordability crisis. Despite robust construction, unsold inventory stands at four months, well below its 25-year average. Private builders complain they can't get land permitted to meet demand. Low-income housing advocates complain housing prices are out of reach for many Americans, and that government subsidies have been slashed.

I am not an economist, though if you keep reading, you'll find I can use selective data points to my advantage with the best of them. I was a real estate reporter for this newspaper through several real estate crises, as well as a Wall Street REIT analyst; I am now a money manager. I currently own stocks in several homebuilders; so I am putting my money where my mouth is.

Of course, over the past 25 years we have seen numerous real estate busts. However, steep price declines have typically been driven by local economic factors -- oil woes lead to weakness in Texas in the '80s; aerospace and defense layoffs soften up prices in LA in the '90s; a contraction on Wall Street hurts New York co-op prices.

What we have never seen in this country is a collapse of home prices without also seeing local economic weakness or significant capacity growth. Absent those factors, housing markets just don't collapse under their own weight. Herewith are some of the myths put forth by the housing bubble Chicken Littles.

-- Myth GBP 1. There is too much capacity: According to Census data, over the past 10 years, housing permits have averaged about 1.63 million units per year -- including multifamily units. Household formation has averaged 1.49 million families per year. So far, so good. But here is where the data gets murky. Roughly 6% of the new home sales were for second homes (I have seen estimates that the number is actually twice as high), according to UBS. And while there are no precise numbers on this, approximately 360,000 units every year were torn down either because they were nonfunctional, or because they were "tear-downs." When the latter two numbers are taken into account, the real number of new homes is closer to 1.2 million, or 19% fewer than the average number of new households formed each year.

-- Myth GBP 2. Risky mortgage products are fueling house appreciation: Sages from Warren Buffett to Alan Greenspan have warned of the increased risk from the use of new mortgage products, particularly adjustable-rate mortgages and interest-only mortgages. The theory here is that buyers are extending themselves to make payments, and when their mortgages reset they will be in trouble. Put aside the fact that only a year ago Mr. Greenspan was advocating the use of ARMs ("American consumers might benefit if lenders provided greater mortgage product alternatives to the traditional fixed-rate mortgage," he told the Credit Union National Association last year), these concerns are wildly overstated. As virtually every mortgagee in the country knows, most ARMs are fixed rate for the first two to seven years. Virtually all have 2% interest-rate caps. The average American owns his home for seven years. Why pay several hundred basis points to lock in rates he is highly unlikely to take advantage of? Moreover, very little equity has been paid off by a homeowner in the first seven years of a 30-year loan, so consumers have been effectively overspending on interest rates for generations. As Mr. Greenspan said in his 2004 speech, "the traditional fixed-rate mortgage may be an expensive method of financing a home."

-- Myth GBP 3. Speculators are Driving Home Prices: The media today is chock-full of stories of day-trading dot-com refugees who have found their calling buying homes and condos "on spec," with the hope of flipping the property for a higher price. Earlier this month, one Wall Street analyst published an article with the catchy headline: "Investors Gone Wild: An Analysis of Real Estate Speculation." Scary stuff. Here, again, some common-sense thinking is in order. In Manhattan, where I live, friends buy apartments kicking and screaming, convinced they top-ticked the housing market. Is Manhattan special? Are speculators flipping Palm Beach mansions? Bay Area three-bedroom homes? Newton, Mass., Tudor homes? I don't think so. Yet these markets are experiencing the same price appreciation as Las Vegas, Phoenix and Florida, where real estate investors are supposedly driving prices higher.

Anyone waiting for prices to collapse before buying a home is likely to be in for a disappointment. According to the Homeownership Alliance, new household formation, replacement demand and second-home demand will require about two million homes per year to be built over the next decade. This year, the number is likely to be around two million, the highest number since the 1970s -- even as the number of households has grown by over 50% since 1975. Therefore, there is a large cumulative deficit in housing that will take years to correct even if annual housing starts continue at these record levels.

---

To the cynical, it is seductive to claim that every piece of good news is a bit fraudulent. And real estate has certainly been subject to boom and bust cycles. But bubbles happen when prices become unhinged from intrinsic value. Homes are not stocks; their "intrinsic value" can only be in the eye of the beholder. A house has utility. Rational people might be willing to pay more for a water view, or for living close to work, or for a larger loo. Such voluntary economic decisions are neither irrational nor exuberant.

It's time to stop being alarmist about home prices. To the extent policy makers want to modulate home-price appreciation, they would do well to relax zoning laws, or stimulate development of low-income housing through tax subsidies. Since those things are not likely to happen overnight, housing prices are likely to cool off slowly, if at all.

---

Mr. Barsky is managing partner of Alson Capital Partners, LLC.

(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Is There A Housing Bubble?" -- WSJ Aug. 4, 2005)

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050728000106]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050728e17s00024


Heard on the Street
Wall Street Finds a New Gusher --- Commercial-Mortgage Securities Are Headed Toward a Record Year As Real-Estate Financing Shifts
By Christine Haughney
961 words
28 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
C1
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

INVESTORS' LOVE AFFAIR with real estate is producing a record year for commercial mortgage-backed securities, signaling a further shift in real-estate financing from banks to Wall Street.

Cash is flooding into the market, where mortgages for skyscrapers, strip malls and other commercial properties are bundled together and sold off as bonds to investors varying from pension funds and insurance companies to hedge funds and wealthy investors.

That strong demand, however, is driving down the yields investors receive. And some bankers fear the rush into the bonds may even loosen lending standards, allowing real-estate buyers to borrow more and thus drive up property prices.

In other words, investors could be putting themselves at risk if their zealousness to lend by purchasing mortgage bonds causes property buyers to overreach.

"What is supporting real-estate prices?" asks Rob Brennan, who runs Credit Suisse First Boston's real-estate finance and securitization group. "It's the availability of competitively priced debt. That's thanks to the public CMBS market."

Real-estate owners borrowed $72 billion through CMBS debt in the first half of 2005, compared with a record $94 billion for all of 2004, according to the Commercial Real Estate Securities Association. The CMBS market has grown tenfold during the past decade, with about $500 billion of securities outstanding.

"CMBS is slowly eating away market share from traditional real-estate lenders like banks and life-insurance companies," said John Westerfield, a Morgan Stanley managing director responsible for real-estate lending. That may be why traditional lenders Bank of America Corp. and Wachovia Corp. now also happen to run the leading CMBS operations.

Sam Zell, a well-known real-estate investor and chairman of Equity Office Properties Trust, the biggest office-building owner in the country, believes that the CMBS market has removed some of the clubbiness in the industry, allowing people to raise funds even if they don't have relationships with bankers. "It's made the overall commercial real-estate market more viable to everybody," Mr. Zell said.

For CMBS investors, the insatiable thirst for yield in a low-yield world is driving much of the demand. While yields on CMBS bonds have fallen, they still offer higher payouts than most government and corporate bonds. But with so many players flooding the CMBS market, returns for investors also are less rewarding than in the past: According to J.P. Morgan, the yield on a single-A-rated CMBS dropped to 5.23% from 5.88% three years ago, while the yield premium the bonds pay above Treasury securities dropped to one percentage point from 1.35 percentage points.

"People are taking more risk for less reward," said Ken Cohen, a Lehman Brothers managing director who puts together CMBS deals.

Still, the yield advantage to other bonds is still attractive enough for many investors. Putnam Investments, for example, now holds CMBS in more than 10% of its active accounts, compared with less than 1% two years ago. "As long as [yield] spreads stay where they are, we're going to be heavily involved," said Rob Bloemker, managing director and team leader of the mortgage-backed securities and government group for Putnam.

Which is why some in the industry fear that real-estate owners will keep borrowing more and more, a real problem should the property market pull back. But it isn't just property buyers who are piling in.

"The real pressure is coming from the developers," said Mark Finerman, who heads the real-estate finance group for RBS Greenwich Capital. Indeed, gung-ho developers can get a loan to break ground on a new building in Manhattan for as little as a 5% down payment on the property.

The CMBS market grew out of the Resolution Trust Corp., which was created to sell off assets of failed savings and loans in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The RTC issued nearly $15 billion of commercial mortgages, which Wall Street firms soon found a way to turn into bonds, with each bond divvied up into individual "tranches" that allow buyers to pick their preferred level of risk.

But conventional developers were slow to adopt CMBS financing. They already had age-old relationships with traditional bankers and insurance companies. While CMBS offered better rates, developers disliked the restrictions against paying off debts early and making changes to buildings and having less contact with bankers.

"We stayed away from them for years," said Gentry Hoit, executive vice president of capital transactions for national office landlord Shorenstein Co. That was then: Recently, Shorenstein used CMBS debt to buy office towers like 125 Park Ave. in New York City and 45 Fremont St. in San Francisco.

The CMBS market seized up along with other credit markets in the wake of the 1998 Russian debt crisis, and the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks also scared off some investors who didn't want to own bonds backed by loans on any one property market. But the market came back, helped by the fact that more loans now routinely back each bond. That makes the bonds less susceptible to the fortunes of a few buildings.

--- 

                                  Bigger Slice 
 
  Commercial mortgage bonds (CMBS) make up a larger percentage of the U.S. 
commercial real estate debt market. 
 
  1994: $952 billion total 
 
  -- Banks: 39% 
  -- Life insurance companies: 21% 
  -- Agency and government pools: 14% 
  -- Savings &Loans: 13% 
  -- Other: 8% 
  -- CMBS: 5% 
 
  2004: $2.3 trillion total 
 
  -- Banks: 43% 
  -- CMBS: 18% 
  -- Agency and government pools: 14% 
  -- Life insurance companies: 11% 
  -- Savings &Loans: 8% 
  -- Other: 6% 
 
  Source: Capital Trust

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050728000090]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050728e17s0001o


Politics & Economy
New Data Bode Well for U.S. Growth
By Rafael Gerena-Morales
765 words
28 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

New orders for durable-goods rose strongly in the U.S. in June, suggesting that business investment, an important pillar of economic growth, could accelerate after a slowdown earlier this year.

The U.S. Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured durable goods -- products like cars, computers and industrial machinery -- increased $2.9 billion (2.4 billion euros), or 1.4%, to $215.4 billion in June. That followed a 6.4% May increase. Earlier gains had been driven by surging orders for airplanes and parts received by companies like Boeing Co. But the latest report showed solid underpinning to business investment outside of this sector. Excluding transportation equipment, new orders were up 2.6% in June after a 0.9% rise the month before.

Economists watch durable-goods orders closely because they are considered an indicator of future economic activity. The numbers are "really encouraging," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities. "It looks like the capital-goods sector is kicking into high gear again. This bodes well for second-half growth."

Other reports on economic growth were encouraging. The Commerce Department reported that sales of new, single-family houses in June rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nearly 1.4 million units, a record. The sales rate was up 4% from the month before, and 14% from a year earlier. Economists took it as yet another sign that the housing boom continued unabated, though the average and median prices of new homes fell for the month.

It has been clear for several weeks now that consumer spending and housing are on a firm footing as the economy moves into the second half. The outlook for business investment is less certain. Investment showed some signs of slowing a few months ago. In the first quarter, for instance, business investment grew at a 4.1% annual rate, according to Commerce Department figures, the slowest pace of growth since early 2003.

Economists say part of the slowdown was tied to the expiration of tax incentives last year, which encouraged businesses to make investments in 2004 while the incentives still applied. The latest durable-goods report indicates that businesses have shrugged off uncertainties and are poised to resume robust spending on equipment, economists say.

The report was the latest in a series of recent indicators that suggest the industrial sector and business investment are gathering steam. Early in the month, the Institute for Supply Management said its monthly survey of supply managers rebounded in June, in part because of a surge in new orders. Moreover, regional Federal Reserve banks in Philadelphia and New York have reported increases in their measures of industrial activity.

Though recent earnings reports have been mixed, several blue-chip companies have pointed to what seems to be an improving outlook for business investment. Last week, Ingersoll-Rand Co., the maker of industrial equipment, boosted its full-year earnings guidance, citing strong orders. Texas Instruments Inc. reported strong demand for semiconductor chips for cellphones. And General Electric Co. reported double-digit gains in orders for the second quarter.

Highlighting the improving outlook, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said in testimony to Congress last week, "Business investment in equipment and software seems to be on a solid upward trajectory in response to supportive conditions in financial markets and the ongoing need to replace or upgrade aging high-tech and other equipment."

Excluding aircraft and defense, new orders for capital goods rose to nearly $69 billion in June, up 3.8% from the month before and 11.1% from a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported. Economists watch this indicator closely for signs of underlying business demand.

New orders for computers and electronic products, up four of the past five months, rose by $3 billion, or 8.6%, to $38.2 billion. The category was led by gains in communications equipment, which increased by $1.3 billion.

"The numbers were somewhat stronger than expected [and] very broad-based," said Joel L. Naroff, president and chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors. "This seems to indicate a fair amount of [business] confidence out there." It also indicates that business investment is "likely to stay solid the rest of the year," he said.

Moreover, the strong capital-spending data validate the Fed's view that business investment remains healthy, which means more interest-rate increases are imminent, Mr. Naroff said.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see additional information on this story in the Online Journal at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJE000020050728e17s00002


International News
Durable-Goods Orders, Sales Of New Homes Increase in U.S. --- Data Suggest Acceleration Of Business Investment And Bode Well for Growth
By Rafael Gerena-Morales
778 words
28 July 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A4
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

New orders for durable-goods rose strongly in the U.S. in June, suggesting that business investment, an important pillar of economic growth, could accelerate after a slowdown earlier this year.

The U.S. Commerce Department reported yesterday that new orders for manufactured durable goods -- products like cars, computers and industrial machinery -- increased $2.9 billion, or 1.4%, to $215.4 billion in June. That followed a 6.4% May increase. Earlier gains had been driven by surging orders for airplanes and parts received by companies like Boeing Inc. But the latest report showed solid underpinning to business investment outside of this sector. Excluding transportation equipment, new orders were up 2.6% in June after a 0.9% rise the month before.

Economists watch durable-goods orders closely because they are considered an indicator of future economic activity. The numbers are "really encouraging," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities. "It looks like the capital-goods sector is kicking into high gear again. This bodes well for second-half growth."

Other reports on economic growth were encouraging. The Commerce Department reported that sales of new, single-family houses in June rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nearly 1.4 million units, a record. The sales rate was up 4% from the month before, and 14% from a year earlier. Economists took it as yet another sign that the housing boom continued unabated, though the average and median prices of new homes fell for the month.

It has been clear for several weeks now that consumer spending and housing are on a firm footing as the economy moves into the second half. The outlook for business investment is less certain. Investment showed some signs of slowing a few months ago. In the first quarter, for instance, business investment grew at a 4.1% annual rate, according to Commerce Department figures, the slowest pace of growth since early 2003.

Economists say part of the slowdown was tied to the expiration of tax incentives last year, which encouraged businesses to make investments in 2004 while the incentives still applied. The latest durable-goods report indicates that businesses have shrugged off uncertainties and are poised to resume robust spending on equipment, economists say.

The report was the latest in a series of recent indicators that suggest the industrial sector and business investment are gathering steam. Early in the month, the Institute for Supply Management said its monthly survey of supply managers rebounded in June, in part because of a surge in new orders. Moreover, regional Federal Reserve banks in Philadelphia and New York have reported increases in their measures of industrial activity.

Though recent earnings reports have been mixed, several blue-chip companies have pointed to what seems to be an improving outlook for business investment. Last week, Ingersoll-Rand Co., the maker of industrial equipment, boosted its full-year earnings guidance, citing strong orders. Texas Instruments Inc. reported strong demand for semiconductor chips for cellphones. And General Electric Co. reported double-digit gains in orders for the second quarter.

Highlighting the improving outlook, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said in testimony to Congress last week, "Business investment in equipment and software seems to be on a solid upward trajectory in response to supportive conditions in financial markets and the ongoing need to replace or upgrade aging high-tech and other equipment."

Excluding aircraft and defense, new orders for capital goods rose to nearly $69 billion in June, up 3.8% from the month before and 11.1% from a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported. Economists watch this indicator closely for signs of underlying business demand.

New orders for computers and electronic products, up four of the past five months, rose by $3 billion, or 8.6%, to $38.2 billion. The category was led by gains in communications equipment, which increased by $1.3 billion.

"The numbers were somewhat stronger than expected [and] very broad-based," said Joel L. Naroff, president and chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors. "This seems to indicate a fair amount of [business] confidence out there." It also indicates that business investment is "likely to stay solid the rest of the year," he said.

Moreover, the strong capital-spending data validate the Fed's view that business investment remains healthy, which means more interest-rate increases are imminent, Mr. Naroff said.

---

The Economy
Existing-Home Sales Rise 2.7%, Paced by Demand for Condos
By Kemba Dunham
747 words
26 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Home sales rocketed to new highs last month, led by America's insatiable appetite for condominiums.

The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing, or previously owned, homes rose 2.7% in June from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.33 million units, the fastest pace on record. The previous record was 7.18 million, set in April.

Sales rose for all types of homes in all regions of the U.S., but the star performers were condos and cooperatives, where the sales pace has been running twice as fast as for single-family homes. The trade group's report said sales of condos rose 4.5% in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 960,000 units, the fourth consecutive month that sales of condos hit a record.

Sales of single-family homes rose 2.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.37 million, also a record.

During the second quarter, condo sales were up about 37% on an annualized basis, compared with 22% for single-family homes.

Prices for condos also are higher than and are rising faster than prices for single-family homes. Last year, the nationwide median price of a condo was $193,600, up 17% from the previous year, according to the group. The median price of a single-family home was $184,100, up 8.3% from the previous year.

In June, the national median existing-home price for all housing types was $219,000, up 14.7% from a year earlier. The June rise was the strongest increase since November 1980, when year-over-year price appreciation was 15.6%. The median price of a condo was $223,500 last month, up 14.8% from a year earlier. Median means that half of the homes sold for more and half sold for less.

David Lereah, the Realtors association's chief economist, attributed the strength in condo sales to empty nesters who are downsizing from larger single-family homes and young professionals who might have rented in previous years but now are tending to buy instead of rent. The jump in condo sales and prices also reflects investor purchases, he said, as well as interest-only loans being used to finance many condos. "That worries me, because I'm not that comfortable with the stability of interest-only loans," he added.

Condo sales are strong nationwide and have reached frenzied levels in Miami, Las Vegas and San Diego. There is some concern that these markets could peak soon, just as developers are adding lots of new supply to the market. In Chicago, for instance, some condo developers have reported slower-than-expected sales in recent months because buyers have so many choices.

As inventories rise, economists expect home-price appreciation to begin to slow. Total housing inventory levels rose 3.8% at the end of June to 2.65 million existing homes, which represents a 4.3-month supply at the current sales pace. The supply of homes on the market has been inching up since January's record low of 3.8 months, but is still relatively low.

"We don't want to see this measure going up too much, but I would be more concerned if we start to see the month supply of new homes going up as opposed to existing homes," said J.P. Morgan Chase economist Haseeb Ahmed. "You can't just take new homes off the market."

Mr. Lereah of the Realtors group said he expects home sales to remain robust in the second half. "There's a lot of momentum right now, with all the major housing measures going strong," he said. "There will be signs of a slowdown only if mortgage rates go up."

---

Online Today: WSJ.com subscribers can see how home prices have climbed over the past 25 years, plus read the latest economic reports, at WSJ.com/OnlineToday.

--- 

                          Window on Housing 
 
Existing-home sales by region, seasonally adjusted at annual rate, in 
millions of units 
 
                       2005      PCT. 
REGION              JUNE   MAY   CHG. 
 
West                1.73  1.64  +5.5% 
Northeast           1.23  1.19  +3.4% 
Midwest             1.63  1.60  +1.9% 
South               2.74  2.71  +1.1% 
U.S.                7.33  7.14  +2.7% 
 
Source: National Association of Realtors

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Politics & Economy
U.S. Home Sales Hit Record Pace, As Condos Lead
By Kemba Dunham
439 words
26 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

U.S. home sales rocketed to new highs last month, led by America's insatiable appetite for condominiums.

The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing, or previously owned, homes rose 2.7% in June from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.33 million units, the fastest pace on record. The previous record was 7.18 million in April.

Sales rose for all types of homes in all regions of the U.S., but the star performers were condos and cooperatives, where the sales pace has been running twice as fast as for single-family homes. The NAR report said that sales of condos rose 4.5% in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 960,000 units, the fourth consecutive month that sales of condos hit a record. Sales of single-family homes rose 2.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.37 million, also a record.

During the second quarter, condo sales were up nearly 40% on an annualized basis, compared with 22% for single-family homes.

Prices for condos also are higher than and rising faster than prices for single-family homes. Last year, the median price of a condo in the U.S. was $193,600 (160,494 euros), up 17% from the previous year, according to the NAR. The median price of a single-family home was $184,000, up 8.3% from the previous year.

In June, the national median price for all housing types was $219,000, up 14.7% from a year ago, when the median price was $191,000. The June rise was the strongest increase since November 1980 when year-over-year price appreciation was 15.6%. The median price of a condo was $223,500 last month, up 14% from a year earlier. Median means that half of the homes sold for more and half sold for less.

David Lereah, the NAR's chief economist, attributes the strength in condo sales to empty nesters who are downsizing from larger single-family homes and young professionals who might have rented in previous years but are now tending to buy instead of rent. The jump in condo sales and prices also reflects investor purchases, he said, as well as interest-only loans that are being used to finance many condos. "That worries me, because I'm not that comfortable with the stability of interest-only loans," he added.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest U.S. economic reports, at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

International News
U.S. Home Sales Continue Rise
By Jeff Bater Dow Jones Newswires
398 words
26 July 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A3
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

The U.S. housing sector in June broke yet another record as sales of previously owned homes again exceeded expectations and climbed thanks to tumbling mortgage rates.

Home resales rose to a 7.33 million annual rate last month, up 2.7% from May's revised 7.14 million pace and breaking April's record rate of 7.18 million, the National Association of Realtors said yesterday.

The level of resales in June beat Wall Street expectations. Analysts predicted a 7.14 million rate of sales of previously owned homes.

"Obviously, the housing market's hot right now," NAR chief economist David Lereah said. "Mortgage rates have fallen three consecutive months. The economy has been improving. That combination has provided a great deal of support in terms of demand for home-buying."

The average 30-year mortgage rate was 5.58% last month, down from 5.72% in May, according to Freddie Mac. The rate was 6.29% in June 2004.

Inventories rose 3.8% at the end of June to 2.65 million existing homes available for sale, representing 4.3 months of supply at the current sales pace. "The irony is that housing inventory is tight enough to boost prices but not enough to curb overall sales," said Al Mansell, NAR president.

The median home price increased to $219,000, compared with a revised $206,000 in May, and was was nearly 15% higher than June 2004's $191,000.

Existing home sales rose throughout the U.S. Demand advanced 3.4% in the Northeast, 1.9% in the Midwest, 1.1% in the South and 5.5% in the West.

The NAR's Mr. Lereah observed that interest rates have edged a bit higher since the period reflected in the latest report. "We do expect a modest slowing in the numbers you are seeing today," he said. "I do worry going forward about the interest-only loans and option [adjustable-rate mortgages] now on the market."

Mr. Lereah expects strong demand for homes to continue -- just not at the levels reflected by these numbers. "I see sales tempering but still [remaining] at very, very high levels," he said.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest U.S. economic reports,at WSJ.com/JournalLinks

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050725e17q0001m


The Economy
Weekly Salaries Rise an Average Of 5.7% in U.S.
By Rafael Gerena-Morales
709 words
20 July 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

U.S. workers saw surprisingly large increases in pay at the end of 2004, according to a new report from the government that takes a comprehensive look at employment and wage trends across 317 of the country's largest counties.

The Labor Department report said weekly salaries rose an average of 5.7% in the fourth quarter from a year earlier. The gain seemed to be bolstered by commissions and end-of-year bonuses, which are included in the counts.

The report showed wages are growing, from suburban areas like Williamson County, near Austin, Texas, to big cities like New York. It also helped clarify a muddled national picture on the state of worker pay. Economists have been puzzled for months about why national income seems to be rising at a healthy pace while measures of hourly wages are barely keeping up with inflation.

The latest report lends weight to the argument that end-of-year bonuses and commissions were a factor, economists say.

The statistics showed that weekly wages averaged $812 throughout the nation. Workers in Williamson saw the biggest increases in weekly wages, with a 17.8% jump to $893 from a year earlier. Williamson County, the home of Dell Inc., is benefiting from the recovery in the tech sector and from robust single-family housing construction, according to Moody's Investors Service.

The county of Rutherford, Tenn., near Nashville, saw employment increase 8.9%, the biggest percentage employment gain in the period. Maricopa County (which includes Phoenix) had the biggest actual gain in new jobs, 75,700 in December 2004 compared with a year earlier.

Dave Iaia, a regional economist with Global Insight, a Waltham, Mass., forecasting firm, says job creation tended to be fastest in warm-weather counties that attracted lots of new families, such as Florida, Arizona and Nevada. Population expansion in those areas is promoting job growth in service sectors such as education, health and tourism, he says.

Joseph Carson, an economist at Alliance Capital, said many of the counties with large wage gains also had strong housing markets. "There could have been a lot of commissions paid out on real-estate transactions and year-end bonuses tied to those sales."

The largest declines in employment occurred in Wayne, Mich., where employment was down 12,600, and Allegheny, Pa., where employment was down 3,900. No county experienced year-over-year declines in average weekly wages, although Kalamazoo, Mich., had the smallest increase in wages, at 0.5%, followed by the 0.7% rise in Richmond, N.Y.

Separately, the Commerce Department said housing starts were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 2.004 million annual rate last month. Permits for future building rose by 2.4% in June to a 2.111 million annual rate after falling a revised 4% in May. "We have to settle for housing demand that is torrid rather than scalding," RBS Greenwich Capital Markets economist Stephen Stanley said. "The bottom line is that the housing sector is still extremely strong."

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest economic reports at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050720000151]
