Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050623e16o00075


New Construction Of U.S. Homes Rose 0.2% in May
By Michael Schroeder
395 words
17 June 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
B2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

WASHINGTON -- New-home construction in the U.S. rose a modest 0.2% in May, the fifth increase in six months, as low mortgage rates remained the engine behind a robust housing market.

Housing starts increased last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2,009,000 units, the Commerce Department said. But the rise was particularly modest after housing starts soared in April -- a 9.4% increase to an annual rate of 2,005,000 units, revised down from the 11% jump initially reported.

Separately, the Labor Department said that new claims for unemployment benefits rose 1,000 last week to 333,000, a tiny increase after a steep decline of 19,999 in the previous week.

Economists dismissed the idea that modest new construction last month and the revised housing number in April indicate a weakening market.

"The latest report was a positive one for the housing sector," said Michael Moran, an economist at Daiwa Securities Inc. "The soft aspects of the report were concentrated in the volatile multifamily sector, while single-family starts remained on solid ground."

The seesaw category of multifamily starts fell about 19% in May to 233,000 units, compared with a nearly 34% jump in April. Single-family activity rose 4.7% in May to 1.704 million, after a 5% increase in April.

The backlog of unstarted homes -- permits issued for homes that haven't begun construction -- declined 4.6% in May, compared with a 6.3% increase in April.

Still, economists said a sturdy backlog suggests single-family starts will remain firm for several more months at least.

Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has said he wasn't concerned about the housing market crashing, despite what he referred to as some "froth" in some markets. He has expressed concern about a raft of potentially risky mortgage products, including so-called interest-only mortgages, that make it easier for home buyers to afford high-price houses.

The average rate on a 30-year mortgage, for instance, has remained below 6% for more than two months, sinking to 5.56% last week, according to Freddie Mac.

---

Journal Link: Meritage Homes CEO John Landon discusses May housing starts in a video report, at WSJ.com/Free.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050617000124]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050617e16h00033


International News
New Construction Of U.S. Homes Rose 0.2% in May
By Michael Schroeder
403 words
17 June 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A3
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

WASHINGTON -- New-home construction in the U.S. rose a modest 0.2% in May, the fifth increase in six months, as low mortgage rates remained the engine behind a robust housing market.

Housing starts increased last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2,009,000 units, the U.S. Commerce Department said. But the rise was particularly modest after housing starts soared in April -- a 9.4% increase to an annual rate of 2,005,000 units, revised down from the 11% jump initially reported.

Separately, the Labor Department said that new claims for unemployment benefits rose 1,000 last week to 333,000, a tiny increase after a steep decline of 19,999 in the previous week.

Economists dismissed the idea that modest new construction last month and the revised housing number in April indicate a weakening market.

"The latest report was a positive one for the housing sector," Michael Moran, an economist at Daiwa Securities Inc., said. "The soft aspects of the report were concentrated in the volatile multifamily sector, while single-family starts remained on solid ground."

The seesaw category of multifamily starts fell about 19% in May to 233,000 units, compared with a nearly 34% jump a month earlier. Meanwhile, single-family activity rose 4.7% in May to 1.704 million, compared with a 5% increase a month earlier.

The backlog of unstarted homes -- permits issued for homes that haven't begun construction -- declined 4.6% in May, compared with a 6.3% increase in April.

Still, economists said a sturdy backlog suggests that single-family starts will remain firm for several more months at least.

In recent remarks, U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said he wasn't concerned about the housing market crashing, despite what he referred to as some "froth" in some markets.

The Fed chairman has expressed concern about a raft of potentially risky mortgage products, including so-called interest-only mortgages, that make it easier for home buyers to afford high-price houses.

The average rate on a 30-year mortgage, for instance, has remained below 6% for more than two months, sinking to 5.56% last week, according to Freddie Mac.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see Gloria Macapagal Arroyo at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050616e16h00028


The Property Report: Market for U.S. Vacation Homes Has Gotten Red Hot --- More Investors Are Buying, Helping Drive Price Surge; A Look at Five Top Gainers
By June Fletcher
1636 words
15 June 2005
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
A9
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

A YEAR AND A HALF ago, David Krahn had never been to New Jersey's shore -- but he plunked down almost a million dollars to buy a house there anyway.

Why? The Philadelphia utilities analyst had heard home prices along the shore were booming. So, for $990,000 (818,000 euros), he and a business partner bought a four-bedroom oceanfront townhouse in Brigantine, New Jersey, a barrier island about an hour away, to use as a summer getaway and part-time rental.

The townhouse appreciated so quickly -- local brokers say they can easily get $1.5 million for it today -- that Mr. Krahn is about to buy another, bigger place nearby. That house costs $1.875 million, but he hopes it, too, will be a gold mine. "Sure it's a risk," he says, "but where else can you make this sort of money so fast?"

The phenomenal U.S. real-estate boom of the past five years is sweeping through the vacation-home market. Lured by relatively low interest rates and the promise of big resale value, investors and regular vacationers alike are snapping up second homes -- or, in some cases, third or fourth homes. And though a rise in interest rates could cool things off, the juggernaut shows few signs of stopping for now, even in upscale areas.

With the trend toward shorter mini-vacations rather than two-week breaks among U.S. workers, the market is especially strong in slightly faded resort towns that are an easy drive from major cities, such as Sayville, New York, and Newport, Rhode Island. Indeed, the entire Jersey shore is popular with buyers, due to its proximity to New York, Philadelphia and Washington, as is the coast between Los Angeles and San Diego.

Places like Pompano Beach, Florida -- which have warehouse stores with minivans in the parking lot, rather than celebrities strolling past chic boutiques -- are coming into their own, too. "It's a come-and-get-it-while-you-can mentality," says local broker Karen Dove, noting inventory there is 30% lower than it was last year.

According to the National Association of Realtors, last year there were a record 2.82 million vacation-home purchases in the U.S., up 16% from the year before. All that demand has sent prices soaring. The price of vacation homes in the U.S. increased 21% during the past year, according to a survey done for The Wall Street Journal by Cambridge, Massachusetts, market-research firm Fiserv/CSW. That's about twice the rate of appreciation of U.S. homes overall. All but two of the towns in the survey, which looked at 54 ZIP Codes with median home prices above $350,000, saw double-digit gains; nearly all were waterfront.

It's not just the wealthy who are buying vacation homes, the Realtors association says. The typical buyer earns $71,000, and buys a home valued at slightly less than $200,000. But, increasingly, buyers who are just looking for a vacation property have to fight with investors for a place in paradise.

A recent report by the Realtors association found that more than one in 10 home purchases last year were by vacation-home buyers who planned to use the property themselves, a 20% rise over the previous year. But about a quarter of U.S. home sales were to investors, up 14% from the year before.

Like Mr. Krahn, many late-to-the-game vacation-home buyers are mixing business and pleasure, renting out their property part of the time.

So, how long can the good times last? Watch the investors. They're often the first ones into an area, and will be the first to sell if they believe prices are starting to soften. Should investors start to pull out of today's hot markets, "it would be time to worry," says Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research for the National Association of Home Builders.

Indeed, vacation towns soon may find their price bubbles bursting. Economist David Stiff of Fiserv/CSW, who prepared our report, says many vacation-home markets are "more overvalued and at greater risk of a price correction" than primary-home markets.

Below, a closer look at the hottest vacation-home market, based on appreciation during the past five years.

Oceanside, California

Five-Year Appreciation: 161.6%

One-Year Appreciation: 28.3%

Median Home Price: $509,000

Even with sparse cultural attractions -- the main draw is the California Surf Museum, where you can learn who invented the "hot curl board" and the "thruster" -- Oceanside has appreciated faster during the past five years than any other community on the list. Oceanside lost favor with vacation buyers after Camp Pendleton, the U.S. Marine Corps base, was built in 1942. But in the past few years, as prices in San Diego, 55 kilometers to the south, rocketed skyward, Oceanside's unglamorous military reputation didn't seem to matter much anymore. Rather, buyers fixated on the fact that Oceanside has some of the lowest beachfront prices in San Diego County, ranging from about $400,000 for a condo to $5 million for a single-family home. The median price won't get you anything on the ocean, but will buy a three-bedroom stucco fixer-upper built in the '80s, about eight kilometers from the water.

Brigantine, New Jersey

Five-Year Appreciation: 149.9%

One-Year Appreciation: 15.2%

Median Home Price: $358,500

Located just north of Atlantic City but without the casinos or glitz, this 17-square-kilometer town -- which comprises an entire barrier island -- benefited from a tunnel built about two years ago connecting it directly to the Atlantic City Expressway. Now beachgoers from Philadelphia, 107 kilometers away, can drive there in a little more than an hour without encountering a single stoplight; it's an easy ride from New York and Washington, too. The island was once a refuge for pirates like Blackbeard and Captain Kidd and a launching spot for whalers, but now has a considerably gentler reputation. While it's still possible to snare a one-bedroom "condotel" in an old converted hotel for about $200,000, newer oceanfront homes sell for more than $4 million. The median price will buy a three-bedroom ranch house on the town's only golf course, but without a water view.

Newport, Rhode Island

Five-Year Appreciation: 141.9%

One-Year Appreciation: 17.7%

Median Home Price: $372,000

At the town's history museum this month, you can see an exhibit on 18th-century shoes, a reminder of the time when Newport was one of the leading ports in America. But the town's economy was wrecked during the American Revolution, when British forces occupied it, and it never quite recovered as an industrial power. So throughout the 19th century, the town transformed itself into a summer resort for the wealthy, like the Vanderbilts and Astors, creating the swanky image that most Americans have of the place today. But Newport is actually diverse, both ethnically and economically. Far more of the town's 26,000 residents are in the middle class than the yachting set. The second-home buyers who have flocked to Newport over the past few years tend to be middle class, too, paying around $300,000 to live in a condo chopped out of one of the city's many huge Victorian homes.

Pompano Beach, Florida

Five-Year Appreciation: 134.9%

One-Year Appreciation: 27.1%

Median Home Price: $355,000

Compared with most of the vacation towns on our list, Pompano Beach is young -- the first two non-Native American residents didn't arrive until 1896, and then promptly named the place after the first fish they had for dinner. The town grew quickly, and now has a population of 88,000. But it never managed to achieve the glamour of Palm Beach, 60 kilometers to the north, or the hipness of Fort Lauderdale, 18 kilometers to the south. The shopping areas grew bedraggled, and the '70s split-levels and older cottages weren't updated. "It wasn't held in high regard," says Ms. Dove, the local real-estate agent. It did, however, have beautiful beaches and lots of deep-water dockage along canals for boaters, at prices much lower than its tonier neighbors. Over the past five years, brokers say, the town has been transformed. Shopping areas and homes have been bulldozed to make way for waterfront townhouses and condos costing upward of $500,000; about two-thirds sell within a month. And the median price? These days, it won't get you much more than a two-bedroom condo on the Intracoastal Waterway.

Sayville, New York

Five-Year Appreciation: 117.7%

One-Year Appreciation: 10.8%

Median Home Price: $435,000

A Victorian time capsule about 80 kilometers from New York City, Sayville had a reputation in the mid-19th century as a summer destination for city dwellers, and even boasted an opera house at one point (it burned down in 1961). But the town lost out in the last half of the 20th century, when more families got cars and started driving to the Hamptons on New York's Long Island. In the past five years, however, jammed roads and sky-high prices in the Hamptons have caused second-home buyers to take a closer look at Sayville. Homes are snapped up so quickly, local real-estate agents say, that inventory is about 20% below last year's levels, even though the median price buys only a nine-room cottage.

---

The Property Report can be reached by email at realestate@wsj.com.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJE000020050615e16f00006


Your Money Matters (A Special Report) --- The Hottest Vacation-Home Markets: Second homes are sizzling; We tell you where -- and why
By June Fletcher
2308 words
13 June 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
R1
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Corrections &Amplifications

THE AREA that became Pompano Beach, Fla., was part of Palm Beach County during its early development, but the city is now in Broward County. An article on the hottest vacation-home markets in Monday's Journal Report noted the historical connection to Palm Beach County but didn't mention the later change of jurisdiction to Broward County.

(WSJ Jun. 15, 2005)

(END)

A YEAR AND A HALF AGO, David Krahn had never been to the Jersey shore -- but he plunked down almost a million dollars to buy a house there anyway.

Why? The Philadelphia utilities analyst had heard home prices along the shore were booming. So, for $990,000, he and a business partner bought a four-bedroom oceanfront townhouse in Brigantine, N.J., a barrier island about an hour away, to use as a summer getaway and part-time rental.

The townhouse appreciated so quickly -- local brokers say they can easily get $1.5 million for it today -- that Mr. Krahn is about to buy another, bigger place nearby. That house costs $1.875 million, but he hopes it, too, will be a gold mine.

"Sure it's a risk," he says, "but where else can you make this sort of money so fast?"

The phenomenal real-estate boom of the past five years is sweeping through the vacation-home market. Lured by relatively low interest rates and the promise of big resale value, investors and regular vacationers alike are snapping up second homes -- or, in some cases, third or fourth homes. And though rising interest rates could cool things off, the juggernaut shows few signs of stopping for now, even in upscale areas.

With the trend toward shorter mini-vacations rather than two-week breaks, the market is especially strong in slightly faded resort towns that are an easy drive from major cities, such as Sayville, N.Y., and Newport, R.I. Indeed, the entire Jersey shore is popular with buyers, due to its proximity to New York, Philadelphia and Washington, as is the coast between Los Angeles and San Diego.

Places like Pompano Beach, Fla. -- which have Costcos with minivans in the parking lot, rather than celebrities strolling past chic boutiques -- are coming into their own, too. "It's a come-and-get-it-while-you-can mentality," says local broker Karen Dove, noting inventory there is 30% lower than it was last year.

According to the National Association of Realtors, last year there were a record 2.82 million vacation-home purchases, up 16% from the year before. All that demand has sent prices soaring. The price of vacation homes increased 21% over the past year, according to a survey done for The Wall Street Journal by Cambridge, Mass., market-research firm Fiserv/CSW. That's about twice the rate of appreciation of homes overall. All but two of the towns in the survey, which looked at 54 ZIP Codes with median home prices above $350,000, saw double-digit gains; nearly all were waterfront.

It's not just the wealthy who are buying vacation homes, the Realtors association says. The typical buyer earns $71,000, and buys a home worth slightly less than $200,000. But, increasingly, buyers who are just looking for a vacation property have to fight with investors for a place in paradise.

A recent report by the Realtors association found that more than one in 10 home purchases last year were by vacation-home buyers who planned to use the property themselves, a 20% rise over the previous year. But about a quarter of the nation's home sales were to investors, up 14% over the year before.

Like Mr. Krahn, many late-to-the-game vacation-home buyers are mixing business and pleasure, renting out their property part of the time. That's actually the best way for investors to preserve the home-mortgage deduction, tax experts say; to get the deduction, the Internal Revenue Service requires owners to use a property 14 days or more a year, or 10% of the time it is rented, whichever is greater.

So, how long can the good times last? Watch the investors. They're often the first ones into an area, and will be the first to sell if they believe prices are starting to soften. Should investors start to pull out of today's hot markets, "it would be time to worry," says Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research for the National Association of Home Builders.

Indeed, vacation towns soon may find their price bubbles bursting. Economist David Stiff of Fiserv/CSW, who prepared our report, says many vacation-home markets are "more overvalued and at greater risk of a price correction" than primary-home markets.

Because vacation homes are a discretionary purchase, when mortgage rates rise, demand will fall faster in vacation-home areas. Mr. Stiff expects prices to rise at half their current rate over the coming year. He expects the weakest performance in places that had the steepest price gains last year, particularly in Florida, Arizona and Southern California. New England and the Jersey shore, which have been cooling a bit for the past year or two, will have softer landings, he predicts.

Below, a closer look at the hottest vacation-home market, based on appreciation over the past five years, in each of five states.

Oceanside, Calif.

[ZIP Code: 92054]

Five-Year Price Appreciation: 161.6%

One-Year Price Appreciation: 28.3%

Median Home Price: $509,000

Even with sparse cultural attractions -- the main draw is the California Surf Museum, where you can learn who invented the "hot curl board" and the "thruster" -- Oceanside has appreciated faster over the past five years than any other community on our list.

Once a summer movie colony for stars like Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, Oceanside lost favor with vacation buyers after Camp Pendleton, the U.S. Marine Corps base, was built in 1942.

But in the past few years, as prices in San Diego, 35 miles to the south, rocketed skyward, Oceanside's unglamorous military reputation didn't seem to matter much anymore. Rather, buyers fixated on the fact that Oceanside has some of the lowest beachfront prices in San Diego County, ranging from about $400,000 for a condo to $5 million for a single-family home. The median price won't get you anything on the ocean, but will buy a three-bedroom stucco fixer-upper built in the '80s, about five miles from the water.

New jobs in biotechnology have helped boost the year-round population to 173,300, but brokers say demand by second-home buyers is the main reason prices are rising so fast. Oceanside broker Marie Jebavy says vacationers are constantly offering her $850,000 or more for her three-bedroom ranch house with an ocean view, almost three times what she paid for it eight years ago. She turns them all down. "If I sold it, I couldn't afford anything near as nice close to the beach," she says.

Brigantine, N.J.

[08203]

Five-Year Price Appreciation: 149.9%

One-Year Price Appreciation: 15.2%

Median Home Price: $358,500

Located just north of Atlantic City but without the casinos or glitz, this 6.4-square-mile town -- which comprises an entire barrier island -- benefited from a tunnel built about two years ago connecting it directly to the Atlantic City Expressway. Now beachgoers from Philadelphia, 67 miles away, can drive there in a little more than an hour without encountering a single stoplight; it's an easy ride from New York and Washington, too.

The island was once a refuge for pirates like Blackbeard and Captain Kidd and a launching spot for whalers, but now has a considerably gentler reputation. The big tourist attraction, ironically, is a Marine Mammal Stranding Center that cares for sick whales.

While it's still possible to snare a one-bedroom "condotel" in an old converted hotel for about $200,000, newer oceanfront homes sell for more than $4 million. The median price will buy a three-bedroom ranch house on the town's only golf course, but without a water view. Two miles of the island's oceanfront remain undeveloped, part of the state's Green Acres program to preserve open space.

Although Brigantine's population doubles during the summer months, many of the 15,000 residents stay year-round because the town has one of the lowest property-tax rates in southern New Jersey. And the town's slim infrastructure bills mean most of those taxes go directly into the school system, helping to make it a top-rated district. "I guess you could call us the anti-Atlantic City," says local real-estate agent Jean Warkala.

Newport, R.I.

[02840]

Five-Year Price Appreciation: 141.9%

One-Year Price Appreciation: 17.7%

Median Home Price: $372,000

At the town's history museum this month, you can see an exhibit on 18th-century shoes, a reminder of the time when Newport was one of the leading ports in America. But the town's economy was wrecked during the American Revolution, when British forces occupied it, and it never quite recovered as an industrial power. So throughout the 19th century, the town transformed itself into a summer resort for the wealthy, like the Vanderbilts and Astors, creating the swanky image that most Americans have of the place today.

But Newport is actually diverse, both ethnically and economically. Far more of the town's 26,000 residents are in the middle class than the yachting set. The second-home buyers who have flocked to Newport over the past few years tend to be middle class, too, paying around $300,000 to live in a condo chopped out of one of the city's many huge Victorian homes. (The swells can still buy an intact one, but they'll have to pony up a lot more -- an 1891 home with eight bedrooms and 91/2 baths is currently on the market for $14 million.)

Liz Taber, a local real-estate agent, says many of the city's second-home buyers are Bostonians and New Yorkers who have been priced out of Nantucket, Martha's Vineyard and Cape Cod. "They buy here when they realize that everything is half the price of what you pay in the city -- even the cocktails," she says.

Pompano Beach, Fla.

[33062]

Five-Year Appreciation: 134.9%

One-Year Appreciation: 27.1%

Median Home Price: $355,000

Compared with most of the vacation towns on our list, Pompano Beach is young -- the first two non-Native American residents didn't arrive until 1896, and then promptly named the place after the first fish they had for dinner. As the southernmost settlement in newly fashionable Palm Beach County, the town grew quickly, and now has a population of 88,000.

But it never managed to achieve the glamour of Palm Beach, 38 miles to the north, or the hipness of Fort Lauderdale, 11 miles to the south. The shopping areas grew bedraggled, and the '70s split-levels and older cottages weren't updated. "It wasn't held in high regard," says Ms. Dove, the local real-estate agent.

It did, however, have beautiful beaches and lots of deep-water dockage along canals for boaters, at prices much lower than its tonier neighbors. Over the past five years, brokers say, the town has been transformed. Shopping areas and homes have been bulldozed to make way for waterfront townhouses and condos costing upward of $500,000; about two-thirds sell within a month. And the median price? These days, it won't get you much more than a two-bedroom condo on the Intracoastal Waterway.

Sayville, N.Y.

[11782]

Five-Year Appreciation: 117.7%

One-Year Appreciation: 10.8%

Median Home Price: $435,000

A Victorian time capsule about 50 miles from New York City, Sayville had a reputation in the mid-19th century as a summer destination for city dwellers, and even boasted an opera house at one point (it burned down in 1961). But the town lost out in the last half of the 20th century, when more families got cars and started driving to the Hamptons. Sayville became just a place where you bought oysters and caught the ferry to Fire Island.

In the past five years, however, jammed roads and sky-high prices in the Hamptons have caused second-home buyers to take a closer look at Sayville. Homes are snapped up so quickly, local real-estate agents say, that inventory is about 20% below last year's levels, even though the median price buys only a nine-room cottage.

The town of about 17,000 has a quirky sense of showmanship. Capping the social season is the annual "boat burn," when officials at the local maritime museum recreate a Viking burial by finding an old boat and setting it ablaze. Last year, some 3,000 visitors came to watch.

Sayville's newfound popularity has been good news for Shannon and Leslie Davis. Just two days after they put their four-bedroom Victorian farmhouse, about a half-mile from the Great South Bay of Long Island, on the market, a vacation-home buyer purchased it for $899,000, more than twice what they paid for it nine years ago. Now the couple has found a new home closer to the water, which they expect will appreciate even faster. Says Ms. Davis, a homemaker, "It's hard to find a town this quaint."

---

Ms. Fletcher is a Wall Street Journal staff reporter in Vienna, Va. She can be reached at june.fletcher@wsj.com.

The Home Front:
WEEKEND JOURNAL
The Home Front: Private Properties
By Troy McMullen
765 words
10 June 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
W10
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

A Dunk . . . After Two Years

BASKETBALL STAR Karl Malone has sold his Salt Lake City house -- for $2.75 million, well below its original $6.1 million asking price.

The eight bedroom, log-and-stone house had been on the market for two years and sold at auction. The buyer was Dwight Manley, Mr. Malone's agent. Mr. Manley says he's buying the house as an investment property and plans to resell it. With the real-estate market's strength, "I thought it was an exceptional value," says Mr. Manley, who wouldn't say how much the home would be listed for.

The 41-year-old Mr. Malone, who retired from the game in February, has also listed his house in Newport Beach, Calif., for $6.8 million. That ocean-view house has five bedrooms and four baths in 6,800 square feet.

The athlete is building a new house in Rustan, La., close to where he grew up. He plans to make that property his main residence, according to Thayne Fisher, vice president of Malone Properties. The company, owned by Mr. Malone, manages his real-estate assets, which also include timber properties.

Mr. Malone, a two-time NBA Most Valuable Player, built the Salt Lake City house in 1997 when he was on the Utah Jazz. It has 11 baths and measures 17,230 square feet. The property also has three guest suites, basketball and tennis courts and two swimming pools. Mr. Malone listed the house shortly after joining the Los Angeles Lakers in 2003. After it didn't sell for a year, he reduced its asking price to $5.75 million, and put it up for auction earlier this year. J.P. King Auction Co. handled the sale.

Brokers say the home's original asking price was high for Salt Lake City. The median price of a single-family home there is $204,311, according to the Utah Association of Realtors. Brokers say high-end buyers usually prefer to buy properties in upscale nearby communities such as Park City. The median price for houses in Park City is $711,000. Sales of existing homes in the Park City area rose 53.5% in the first quarter of this year, compared with 17.6% in Salt Lake City, according to the Realtor group.

Mr. Malone bought his Newport Beach house soon after joining the Lakers in the summer of 2003, says the listing agent, Roseanne Levan, of Coldwell Banker Previews International in Newport Beach. The house includes a media room and a master suite with terrace. The median single-family home price in Newport Beach is among the highest in the country at $1,297,500, according to DataQuick, a real-estate research firm in La Jolla, Calif.

Simplifying by Selling

CALIFORNIA INVESTOR and former Shaklee Corp. chief executive Gary Shansby has put on the market his 360-acre Sonoma, Calif., estate for $35 million. It's one of the most expensive San Francisco Bay-area listings on the market. Mr. Shansby, 67 years old, said he and his wife want to "simplify our lives now" as he recovers from a bout of prostate cancer. The couple plans to buy a smaller home in Mexico when the house sells.

Mr. Shansby paid just over $5 million for the land in 1988. An 11,600-square-foot, Tuscan-style main house was built five years later on the property, in the heart of Sonoma Valley wine country. The house has two bedrooms and three baths, and the property includes a pool, spa and 10-acre vineyard with Syrah grapes. About 20 miles north of the Golden Gate Bridge, the site also includes a two-bedroom guest house and horse stables.

From Shaklee to TSG

In the 1970s, Mr. Shansby took over as chairman and chief executive of Shaklee, a Pleasanton, Calif., maker of personal-care products. After leaving Shaklee, he co-founded a private-equity investment concern, Shansby Group, in 1987. (The company is now called TSG Consumer Partners LLC.) Last summer, the executive was diagnosed with cancer. Now cancer-free, Mr. Shansby sits on the board of the Prostate Cancer Foundation, founded by Michael Milken.

Bay Area real estate has soared since the dot-com bust. The median price for a single-family home in the nine-county region is $622,000 -- more than three times the national average, according to DataQuick. Betty Brachman of Sotheby's International Realty has the listing.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Personal Finance
Home Sales Headed for Record '05 --- Realtors' Forecast Reverses Expectations for Slowdown; Low Rates Fuel Optimism
By Kemba J. Dunham
651 words
9 June 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
D2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Housing industry economists raised their forecast for home sales this year, noting that demand remains strong due to lower-than-expected mortgage rates.

Economists at the National Association of Realtors, a trade group, said they expect home sales to total a record 8.13 million units in 2005, up 1.8% from last year. Of that total, sales of previously owned homes are expected to reach 6.89 million units, up 1.6% from 2004. Sales of newly built homes are expected to total 1.24 million this year, up 3.2% from 2004.

When the NAR released a previous housing industry forecast in February, the group said it expected existing-home sales to decline 2% and new-home sales to decline 6.2%, in both cases due to rising interest rates. Instead, long-term interest rates have fallen this year. Last week, Freddie Mac said that rates on conventional 30-year fixed-rate mortgages were 5.6%, down from about 6.4% a year ago.

"We expected that mortgage rates would go up much higher, but it looks like they will be in a very favorable range," which will keep demand strong, says Lawrence Yun, a senior economist at the NAR.

The trade group also estimates that home builders will have started construction on 2.02 million home units this year, up 3.4% from 2004 and the highest level of new-home starts since 1973.

Although some economists worry that home builders may be creating too much supply, Mr. Yun doesn't believe that is the case. "Home-price appreciation over the last three years has been nearly 10% nationwide in each of the years, and that implies that there is a housing shortage," he says. "To alleviate the shortage, we will need close to two million housing starts, and we suggest that will be the case this year."

The NAR also estimates that home prices will continue to climb. The national median existing-home price for all housing types is expected to rise 8.8% in 2005 to $201,500, while the typical new-home price will increase 5.7% to $233,600, the group says.

"There are glaring affordability problems developing in many of the hot markets, but the fact that prices are as high as they are means that the transactions are occurring," says David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. "The market is due for some cooling off, but how that evolves depends on the long-term interest rates."

Even markets that have been left behind in the housing boom, such as those in the Midwest, may see some increases this year, according to the NAR. Cities like Detroit and Columbus, Ohio, saw little appreciation in home prices last year. But economists expect home sales to improve in those areas as the Midwest becomes more affordable compared with the rest of the country and lures more buyers. They also see the job market there strengthening, which could further strengthen the housing market there.

Mr. Seiders says that "two wild cards" in the overall U.S. market are "overly aggressive" lenders offering such deals as interest-only loans, and speculative investors. But he doesn't see them being facilitators of a market crash. As long as the economic expansion continues at a steady pace with strong job growth, says Mr. Seiders, "I think the best bet is a slowdown on the price appreciation and a rebalancing of the housing market without a lot of damage."

The NAR estimates that the U.S. gross domestic product is expected to grow 3.5% in 2005, with the unemployment rate holding around 5.2% for the rest of the year. It also predicts modest inflation.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050609000139]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050609e1690003i


The Economy
Home Prices Kept Climbing At 2.2% Clip in First Quarter --- Low Interest Rates Powered Market's Continuing Boom; May Manufacturing Cooled
By Michael Schroeder
582 words
2 June 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

WASHINGTON -- With low mortgage rates fueling a long housing boom, home prices continued to rise briskly during the first three months of the year.

Home prices rose 2.2% nationwide in the first quarter, a rate unchanged from last year's fourth quarter, according a quarterly index reported by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight. Prices rose 12.5% in the 12 months through March, compared with 11.9% for the comparable period the year before, Ofheo said.

While housing prices continued their swift climb, U.S. manufacturing growth moderated in May. The Institute for Supply Management, which polls purchasing managers at more than 400 industrial companies, reported that its index of manufacturing activity stood at 51.4 in May, down from 53.3 in April and 55.2 in March -- the sixth consecutive monthly decline. Still, the reading is above 50, which indicates growth.

Housing prices are ballooning in some states. Nevada had the highest price appreciation of 31.2% in the 12-month period, followed by California and Hawaii, with 25.4% and 24.4%, respectively. Texas and Indiana showed the slowest price increases of 3.8% and 4.1%, respectively, Ofheo reported.

"The House Price Index shows the rise in house prices continues at an extremely strong pace and raises the potential for declines in some areas later on," said Ofheo Chief Economist Patrick Lawler.

The quarterly house-price index, which uses data supplied by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, measures price movements on sales or refinancings of single-family homes whose mortgages are owned or guaranteed by the government-sponsored enterprises.

In addition, the National Association of Realtors reported that sales of existing homes set a record in April. The Pending Home Sales Index, which tracks sales contracts that have been signed but not closed, was 128.2, up 3.6% from March.

Low interest rates continue to fuel the boom. Fixed 30-year mortgage rates averaged 5.61% last week, excluding fees, down from 6.24% a year ago, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

"Home sales were expected to be tapering this year, but the index tells us that historic home sales are likely to continue," David Lereah, the group's chief economist, said in a statement.

The Institute for Supply Management, in its report, found both the biggest change in inflation pressures since the summer of 1975, along with a drop in hiring for the first time in 18 months.

Rising oil prices are significantly hampering the growth of U.S. industrial manufacturers, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers's most recent Manufacturing Barometer survey. Nearly half of the executives surveyed -- 47% -- cited rising energy prices as a potential barrier to growth during the next 12 months.

"While this represents the longest period of [manufacturing] growth in the last 16 years, the data also indicate that the sector is losing momentum," said Norbert Ore, who directs the ISM survey.

Meanwhile, the Commerce Department said total construction spending grew 0.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $1.066 trillion in April, as office construction surged and activity in the housing market hit a record. Construction spending rose 0.6% in March.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can read the Ofheo news release and scan its housing data, at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050602000131]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Mortgage Rates Fell During Latest Week
Dow Jones Newswires
217 words
27 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
C4
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

NEW YORK -- Fixed-rate home-mortgage rates declined in the week to yesterday, according to Freddie Mac's primary mortgage-market survey.

The survey said 30-year fixed mortgage rates averaged 5.65% this week, with an average fees and points of 0.6 point, compared with last week's 5.71%. A year ago, the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage stood at 6.32%.

The 15-year fixed-mortgage rate averaged 5.21%, down from last week's 5.27% and 5.69% a year ago.

In adjustable-mortgage rates, the five-year Treasury-indexed hybrid ARM was unchanged at 5.07%. The one-year ARM rate stood at 4.21% this week, down from 4.26% last week. A year ago, this rate stood at 3.87%.

Freddie Mac chief economist Frank Nothaft noted that with inflation remaining low, mortgage rates continued to decline, supporting new home sales and fueling the economy.

"Since the end of March long-term bond yields have fallen by more than a half of a percentage point, allowing interest rates on fixed-rate mortgages to decline as well. Consequently, both new and existing home sales in April reached record highs," Mr. Nothaft said.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

The Economy
New-Home Sales Rose in April, Median Price Increased 3.8%
By Jon E. Hilsenrath
553 words
26 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Americans snapped up new homes at an increasing pace in April, another sign the housing boom continues despite longstanding warnings the sector would cool off this year.

The Commerce Department said sales of new single-family homes rose 0.2% in April from the month earlier to a record annual rate of 1.32 million units, though they were revised lower for the month of March. For April, they were up 13.3% from a year earlier.

The median price of a new home rose 3.8% to $230,800 from a year earlier. Median means half the homes sold for more than that, half for less. The price increases on new homes weren't as eye-popping as gains reported Tuesday by the National Association of Realtors on prices for existing homes. The Realtors' report showed median prices of existing homes were 15.1% higher than a year earlier.

One reason for the difference, the supply of new homes for sale is growing more rapidly than the supply of existing homes being put on the market. In April, 2.48 million existing homes were on the market, up 3.1% from a year earlier. By contrast, the supply of new homes on the market rose 15.2% in April from a year earlier to 440,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis, according to the Commerce Department.

"We don't have, as we did a year or two ago, a situation where everything was undersupplied," said Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. "There are some places where supply has pretty much caught up with demand."

But if home-price appreciation is slowing down for new homes, Robert Toll, chief executive of luxury-home builder Toll Brothers Inc., says he isn't seeing it. His company is now selling golf-course homes in Palm Beach for $1.4 million, up from $902,000 a year ago. The company's "mesquite" homes in Phoenix fetch $947,000, compared with $691,000 a year ago. "Every home that is being built is already sold," he said.

Another report showed the U.S. industrial sector in April regained some of its lost momentum. The Commerce Department said U.S. manufacturers received $200.3 billion of orders for durable goods in April, on a seasonally adjusted basis. That was up 1.9% from the month earlier and it was the first monthly increase since December. Orders are considered a leading indicator of manufacturing activity. But the sector is experiencing an uneven recovery. Orders for motor vehicles and defense equipment are down from a year ago. Orders for machinery and capital goods outside the defense sector still are posting double-digit increases when compared with a year earlier.

"High gasoline prices have put the auto industry on the ropes . . . and the surge in imports is hurting consumer industries like appliances and lighting," said Daniel J. Meckstroth, chief economist for the Manufacturers Alliance/MAPI. "However, the fact that nondefense capital-goods orders rose 3.8% in April and are up 9.8% in the last three months versus one year ago indicates that the core of industrial demand remains robust."

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050526000120]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050526e15q00030


International News
U.S. Durable-Goods Orders Log First Monthly Increase of Year
By Jon E. Hilsenrath
487 words
26 May 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A4
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

The U.S. industrial sector has lost some momentum this year, but perhaps not as much as it seemed to be losing a few weeks ago.

The Commerce Department said U.S. manufacturers received $200.3 billion in orders for durable goods in April. That was up 1.9% from the prior month, the first monthly increase since December, and an antidote to other recent surveys of manufacturers showing continued softening in the sector. In the first four months of the year, orders for products like computers, cars and tanks were up a moderate 4.3% from a year ago -- a slowdown from double-digit rises last year.

"The rate of growth is slowing, there is no question," said Daniel J. Meckstroth, chief economist for the Manufacturers Alliance/MAPI.

In a separate report, the Commerce Department said sales of new single-family homes in the U.S. rose 0.2% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.32 million units, from the previous month. Sales, which were revised lower for the month of March, were up 13.3% from a year earlier.

The report was more evidence the housing-market boom continues, though it wasn't marked by the kind of eye-popping gains reported earlier in the week by the National Association of Realtors. The Realtors report showed median prices of existing homes were 15.1% higher than a year earlier.

One reason for the difference: The supply of new homes for sale is growing much more rapidly than the supply of existing homes that are being put on the market. In April, 2.48 million existing homes were on the market for sale, up 3.1% from a year earlier. By contrast, 440,000 new homes were on the market for sale in April, seasonally adjusted, up 15.2% from a year earlier.

"We don't have, as we did a year or two ago, a situation where everything was undersupplied," said Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.

Meanwhile, the manufacturing sector is experiencing a very uneven recovery. Orders for motor vehicles and defense equipment fell from a year ago, and telecommunications-equipment orders dropped sharply in April. But orders for machinery and capital goods outside of the defense sector are still posting double-digit percentage jumps from last year.

"High gasoline prices have put the auto industry on the ropes, defense spending for heavy military equipment is declining early this year, and the surge in imports is hurting consumer industries like appliances and lighting," said Mr. Meckstroth. "However, the fact that nondefense capital goods orders rose 3.8% in April and are up 9.8% in the last three months versus one year ago indicates that the core of industrial demand remains robust."

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050525e15q0001u


Politics & Economy
Sales of Existing U.S. Homes Soared Last Month
A Wall Street Journal News Roundup
496 words
25 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Sales of existing U.S. homes advanced in April at a record pace, driving home prices even higher as cheaper financing refueled the housing boom.

The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes rose 4.5% from the month before to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.18 million units, the fastest pace on record. At the same time, the national median home price was up 15.1% from a year ago to $206,000 (164,000 euros). That marked the biggest increase since November 1980, when prices rose 15.6%.

David Lereah, the NAR's chief economist, said in a news release, "a new record is a bit unexpected, but so is the performance of mortgage interest rates, which have been lower than forecast. When we look at recent job gains, we see all the positive factors coming together to coincide with a powerful demographic demand for housing."

Despite the Federal Reserve's campaign to push up short-term interest rates, longer-term interest rates have been falling. The average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage fell to 5.86% last month from 5.93% in March, according to Freddie Mac.

"There is no evidence that monetary policy has had a dampening influence on the housing market and we view the strong gain in home prices as further evidence of easy money," economists at Bear Stearns wrote in a research note.

In a luncheon speech to the Economic Club of New York last Friday, Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan acknowledged the housing market may be getting overheated. "There are a number of things, which I think suggest at a minimum, there is a little froth in this market," he said. Though he stopped short of suggesting there was a national real-estate bubble, he said "it's hard not to see that there are a lot of local bubbles."

In response, federal banking regulators are planning to issue new guidelines for mortgage lenders early next year. Regulators have cited the recent proliferation of adjustable-rate mortgages and interest-only mortgages, particularly in high-cost markets, as cause for worry.

Existing-home sales are considered a lagging indicator in terms of consumers' response to mortgage rates, since they are booked at closing instead of at contract. But other housing indicators have also displayed continued strength. Housing starts, for instance, jumped 11% in April.

The NAR's report showed that the inventory of homes on the market rose to 4.2 months in April, compared with March's unrevised 4.0 months. Existing-home sales among four regions in the U.S. were mixed: Demand was up 4.3% in the Northeast, up 5.8% in the Midwest, up 7.4% in the South and flat in the West.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest U.S. economic reports, at WSJ.com/JournalLinks

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

International News
U.S. Home Sales Hit a Record
A Wall Street Journal News Roundup
239 words
25 May 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A4
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

Sales of existing U.S. homes advanced in April at a record pace, driving home prices even higher as cheaper financing refueled the housing boom.

The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes rose 4.5% from the month before to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.18 million units, the fastest pace on record. At the same time, the national median home price was up 15.1% from a year ago to $206,000. That marked the biggest increase since November 1980, when prices rose 15.6%.

Despite the Federal Reserve's campaign to push up short-term interest rates, longer-term interest rates have been falling. The average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage fell to 5.86% last month from 5.93% in March, according to Freddie Mac.

In response, federal banking regulators are planning to issue new guidelines for mortgage lenders early next year. Regulators have cited the recent proliferation of adjustable-rate mortgages and interest-only mortgages, particularly in high-cost markets, as cause for worry.

Existing-home sales are considered a lagging indicator in terms of consumers' response to mortgage rates, since they are booked at closing instead of at contract. But other housing indicators have also displayed continued strength. Housing starts, for instance, jumped 11% in April.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050524e15p0000s


The Economy
Existing-Home Sales Rose 4.5% And Prices Leapt 15.1% in April
By Jon E. Hilsenrath
558 words
25 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Sales of existing U.S. homes advanced at a record pace in April, driving home prices even higher as cheaper financing refueled the housing boom.

The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes rose 4.5% from the month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.18 million units, the fastest pace on record.

At the same time, the national median home price was up 15.1% from a year earlier to $206,000. Median means that half of the homes sold for more and half sold for less. It was the biggest increase since November 1980. Back then, home prices were being driven by broad, economywide inflation. Today, by contrast, economywide inflation is relatively dormant, meaning home-price gains in real terms are soaring at an especially astonishing pace.

"When I see increases like this, it does indicate to me that there could be some frenzied buying out there," said David Lereah, chief economist with the Realtors association.

The latest report is likely to get the attention of officials at the Federal Reserve, who are becoming increasingly concerned about froth in the market. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan called attention to it last week in comments to the Economic Club of New York.

When Fed officials met earlier this month, they expected home-price appreciation to moderate in the months ahead, according to minutes of their May 3 monetary policy meeting released yesterday. The latest housing report shows no sign of that happening, and indicates price gains may even be accelerating nationally.

The Fed has raised the short-term federal-funds rate eight times in the past year to 3%. However long-term interest rates haven't moved in sync with the Fed's campaign. The average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage fell to 5.86% last month, from 5.93% in March, according to Freddie Mac. That has added fuel to the housing market.

Developments in the West were emblematic of the momentum behind prices. Sales of homes in the West were flat in April compared with March, at an annual rate of 1.61 million units. The volume of sales was up a modest 2.5% from a year earlier. But median home prices in the West were 21% higher than a year earlier, despite the sales slowdown. Mr. Lereah said this is largely because of tight supplies in the region.In April the supply of existing homes for sale nationwide grew 5% to 2.48 million units. But the added supply wasn't enough to put a cap on price gains.

Some economists regard the existing-home-sales report as a lagging economic indicator, because it is based on contract closings rather than signings. The Realtor association's pending home-sales index, which is based on contract signings, fell 0.3% in March, a sign that some of the April increase might be overstated. But industry officials remain ebullient.

"May is going to be another good month," said Tom Kunz, chief executive of Century 21 Real Estate Corp.

---

Journal Link: See video of Coldwell Banker Real Estate CEO Jim Gillespie discussing the record pace of existing home sales, at WSJ.com/Free.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Personal Finance
Common Sense: Real Estate: Time To Buy or Sell? Probably Neither
By James B. Stewart SmartMoney
903 words
25 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
D3
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

WHEN FEDERAL RESERVE Chairman Alan Greenspan used the word "froth" in connection with the current real-estate market last week, he was rather late to the party. Economists, pundits and journalists have been saying for months that the real-estate market is overheated. About the only people who aren't fretting about soaring real-estate prices are the ever-upbeat real-estate brokers (and even they will say, off the record, that the market is crazy) and, of course, investors making their deposits on unbuilt Florida condos.

Can all these Cassandras actually be right? After all, markets usually factor in the conventional wisdom, and prices are set accordingly. If everyone believes that real-estate prices are about to implode, they already would have imploded. Despite the current chorus of caution, buyers still are lining up to buy real estate. Just yesterday, we learned that existing home sales jumped 4.5% in April to a record 7.18 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors -- far stronger than the flat reading economists were expecting.

I'm not convinced that real estate is in a bubble, or that prices necessarily are headed for an imminent collapse. I'm not selling my apartment or my weekend house in upstate New York to try to capitalize on a market peak.

On the other hand, I wouldn't dream of putting more money into real estate right now, and I wouldn't want to be overleveraged with big mortgages in order to cash in on rising home prices. I can't foresee the future, but I can say to a near certainty that real-estate prices won't keep soaring at an annualized rate in excess of 20%, as they did last year in some areas.

But all of this prompts an important question for first-time home buyers, people who just want a decent place to live and some security for their families. What's someone to do who's stuck paying rent and watching his or her savings steadily fall behind rising home prices?

I know the feeling. I remember vividly trying to save the money for a down payment on a New York apartment during the early and mid-1980s, another period of fast-rising real-estate prices. The more I saved, the more I fell behind. Finally, after 10 years of renting, I landed a book advance that, along with all my savings, became the down payment on a modest apartment. I was convinced I was buying at the top.

New York real-estate prices did plunge, but not until 1991, and they never got as low as the price I paid. So despite my own concerns about high real-estate prices, my advice to first-time buyers who want to purchase a primary residence and who can manage the down payment and monthly mortgage payments, is to ignore all this talk about an overheated market and the likelihood of a coming collapse in prices. Think of real estate less as an investment, and more as a consumer durable -- a necessity.

Even if prices go down, you still will own an asset. If you enjoy it and can meet the monthly payments, what difference does the market value make? I feel the same way regarding people who boast about the soaring value of their homes. So what? Unless they plan to sell it now, and downsize, or move into a less expensive place (highly unlikely), they're no better or worse off than they were before prices took off. And if they're planning to trade up, the even bigger or more luxurious place down the block has appreciated even more than theirs.

First-time buyers can take some comfort that even if they do buy at the top and prices drop, other real estate also will decline. If they want to sell, even at a loss, and trade up to something better, that new home also will have dropped in price. Whatever happens to prices, owning real estate at least puts you on the elevator. You won't be stuck waiting in the basement while everyone else ascends to the penthouse.

Let me emphasize that this advice goes only for first-time buyers of primary residences, though I might also make an exception for buyers who are looking for a second home for their own use and can comfortably afford the payments.

It's true that the real-estate market isn't like the stock market: It moves in longer cycles, and it is less prone to sudden price shifts, let alone collapses. But once a negative market psychology sets in, the decline in real estate can be long and painful, as the 1991 recession made clear for many homeowners. I believe that over time, real estate returns, like those of other asset classes, will revert to their historical norm, which is a markedly lower rate of return than stocks. That means the longer the current boom keeps going, the longer, and harder, the fall.

---

James B. Stewart is an editor at large at SmartMoney magazine and a contributing editor at SmartMoney.com. He may have positions in the stocks he writes about. To read past Common Sense columns, see: www.smartmoney.com/wsj_common[http://www.smartmoney.com/wsj_common] .

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050525000138]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050525e15p0003j


The Economy
Consumer Products Produce Split in the Industrial Sector --- Output of Cars, Furniture, Appliances Fell in April; Producer Prices Rose 0.6%
By Jon E. Hilsenrath
524 words
18 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

In one sector of the economy, consumer-goods manufacturing, there really is a soft patch.

Yesterday's economic reports pointed to robust economic growth, with data indicating that housing construction rebounded in April and inflation pressures built as the economy expanded. But for manufacturers of products like cars, appliances and furniture, it's a different story.

Rising costs and tough international competition are taking a toll. Industrial production declined 0.2% in April, the Federal Reserve said, and manufacturers of consumer products had a lot to do with it. Their output declined 0.9%, the third decline in four months, including a 3% drop in the output of automotive products and a 2.5% drop in the production of furniture, appliances and carpeting.

General Electric Co. last month said it would stop producing a line of midtier refrigerators at a Bloomington, Ind., plant, leaving 470 people out of work. A GE spokeswoman said the facility lost $150 million in the past three years and the product could be upgraded more cheaply in Celaya, Mexico.

In Reno, Nev., Springs Industries Inc., a manufacturer of bed linens and window fashions, said it would move production of window shades and blinds to Mexico, leaving 166 U.S. employees out of work. "The competitive environment continues to get more difficult," said Ted Matthews, a spokesman for Springs. "We have to continue to find ways to improve margins and stay competitive."

Such actions point to a split in the industrial sector. While production of consumer goods languishes as foreign producers take market share, production of business equipment is playing an increasingly important role in the expansion. Output of business equipment rose 0.8% in April and was up 8.4% from a year earlier.

Another report showed that the prices charged by manufacturers were going up. Producer prices rose 0.6% in April, amid rising costs for energy, tobacco and prescription drugs. The core producer-price index, which excludes food and energy items, rose 0.3%, the largest increase in three months.

The report was a fresh signal that some manufacturers are passing on higher raw-material costs to their customers. But here, too, manufacturers of business equipment had more leverage than manufacturers of consumer goods. Producers of capital equipment raised prices 2.9% from a year earlier, while producers of long-lasting consumer goods raised prices 1.9% from a year earlier.

One factor constraining the consumer-goods makers is the power of big-box retailers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Home Depot Inc. to halt price increases at their doors.

Separately, the Commerce Department said home builders broke ground at an increasing rate during April, plowing forward after a late-winter retreat blamed on weather. Housing starts rose 11% last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.038 million units, the Commerce Department said. That marked a rebound after starts tumbled 17.6% in March to 1.836 million.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20050518000148]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020050518e15i0003l


U.S. Economy Shows Signs of Improvement --- Industrial Output Eased In April, but Housing Starts And Wholesale Prices Rose
By Jon E. Hilsenrath
457 words
18 May 2005
The Asian Wall Street Journal
AWSJ
A1
English
(c) 2005 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

New economic reports suggest the U.S. economy is in stronger shape than it appeared to be in just a month ago. But one sector is still clearly struggling: Manufacturing of consumer products like cars, furniture and appliances.

The Federal Reserve said industrial production fell 0.2% in April after a small increase the month before. Manufacturers of consumer products had a lot to do with it. Their output declined for the third time in four months, including a 3% April drop in the output of automotive products and a 2.5% April drop in production of furniture, appliances and carpeting.

Many of these industries are still battling tough import competition, most notably from low-cost producers in places like China and Mexico.

While production faced downward strain in April, the prices charged by producers were facing upward pressure. U.S. wholesale prices rose 0.6% in April, a faster pace than Wall Street expected amid a surge in prices for tobacco and prescription drugs.

Moreover, energy prices rose for a third consecutive month. Overall energy prices increased 2.1% in April after a 3.3% gain in March. That partly reflected a 6.6% gain in prices of residential natural gas -- the largest increase in two years. Gasoline prices rose 2.6%.

The core producer-price index, which excludes food and energy items, rose 0.3% -- the largest increase in three months.

Some economists believe wholesale-price pressures could abate in the months ahead, because the cost of raw materials has eased in recent weeks. For example, oil prices hit a record of about $58 a barrel in early April but dropped about $8 by the end of the month. "By year-end, finished-goods prices will be slowing," said Ian Shepherdson, economist with High Frequency Economics, in a note to clients.

Separately, the Commerce Department said homebuilders broke ground at an increasing rate during April, plowing forward after a late-winter retreat blamed on weather. Financing costs for buyers remain low and home values are moving up.

Housing starts rose 11% last month to a seasonally adjusted 2.038 million annual rate, the Commerce Department said yesterday. March starts tumbled an unrevised 17.6% to 1.836 million, the biggest plunge in 14 years. February starts advanced 1.8% to 2.228 million. Economists, saying housing-market fundamentals remain favorable, expected that better weather on the heels of a cold, rainy, snowy March would help boost starts in April.

---

Journal Link: WSJ.com subscribers can see the latest U.S. economic reports, at WSJ.com/JournalLinks.

Dow Jones & Company Inc.

Document AWSJ000020050517e15i0001q


Personal Finance
Rapid Rise in Home Prices Spreads --- Record Number of Cities See Double-Digit Growth In Median Housing Cost
By James R. Hagerty
449 words
17 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
D2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Rapid home-price inflation spread to more cities in the first quarter, the National Association of Realtors said in a report released last week.

The NAR found that median prices for previously occupied homes rose at double-digit rates from the year-earlier quarter in 66 of the 136 metropolitan statistical areas included in its quarterly survey. That was the highest number of double-digit gains recorded by the NAR since it began compiling such metropolitan tables more than 25 years ago. In last year's fourth quarter, 62 metro areas showed double-digit increases.

The biggest increase recorded in the latest quarter was 46% in Bradenton, Fla. Florida also had two of the other biggest increases -- 36% in both Sarasota and the West Palm Beach-Boca Raton area. Other large gainers included Riverside-San Bernardino, Calif. (33%), Las Vegas (29%), Sacramento, Calif. (27%), and Atlantic City, N.J. (23%).

Six metro areas showed declines: Beaumont-Port Arthur, Texas (-6.5%); Canton, Ohio (-4.5%); Cedar Rapids, Iowa (-1.5%); Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C. (-0.3%); Syracuse, N.Y. (-2.6%); and Waterloo-Cedar Falls, Iowa (-2.6%).

Nationally, the median price was $188,800, up 9.7% from a year earlier. David Lereah, the NAR's chief economist, said in the report that the continued surge in prices reflects a shortage of homes in many areas at a time when low interest rates are bringing more people into the market. Mr. Lereah also contends that immigration and demand for second homes from baby boomers will continue to support the market. He told a gathering of Realtors last week that he expects all but a few markets to "deflate slightly rather than pop."

In a separate report last week, Jan Hatzius, an economist at Goldman Sachs in New York, said the recent further decline in mortgage rates may have given the housing market "another lease on life." But, he said, "the risk of a sharp home-price slowdown -- and outright declines in some regional markets -- is high."

For home shoppers, it all adds up to high anxiety. Daniel Ruben Odio-Paez, who operates DROdio Realty, based in Falls Church, Va., has added a "home-value clock" to his Web site. It shows average home prices in northern Virginia ticking upward at a rate of $10.32 an hour.

---

Journal Link: See an interactive map of the state of the U.S. housing market, and get details on home prices in a dozen cities, at WSJ.com/PersonalJournal

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

The Economy
New York Manufacturing Falls To Lowest Level Since April '03
Dow Jones Newswires
311 words
17 May 2005
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2005, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

NEW YORK -- The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said manufacturing in its district "deteriorated" in May to its lowest level of activity since April 2003, although the outlook for the sector remained positive.

The bank said its Empire State manufacturing index for May dropped to a reading of minus-11.1 versus the revised 2 seen the month before, meaning that more respondents to its survey said that business conditions had worsened compared with those who said business conditions had improved.

The new-orders index fell to minus-7.1 in May, from April's revised minus-1.2, meaning that more were seeing a decline in orders. The employment index softened to 0.2 in May, after April's 8.5. May's job performance was the lowest in more than 2 1/2 years, the New York Fed said.

Economists were reluctant to read too much into the persistent softness in New York manufacturing, because the report is for just one region of the economy, and broader measures of activity recently suggest the U.S. economy isn't weakening substantially.

Price pressures remained a factor for the New York area manufacturers, with May's prices-paid index holding mostly steady at 42, from April's revised 43.1, while the prices-received index in May was 8, versus 13.8 the month before.

Separately, the National Association of Home Builders said its index for sales of new, single-family homes rose to 70 in May from 67 in April. When the index is over 50, it means the number of builders who see "good" sales outnumber those who see "poor" sales. "Builders have seen an uptick in traffic and sales," said association President Dave Wilson.

  Here's the median sale price through April in areas, listed east to west,
